text:
Very good recipe.  Several reviewers have mentioned having a problem with the skin staying intact after scooping out the flesh.  The answer is very simple.  First, be sure to use baking potatoes, as the recipe states.  These have thicker, less delicate skin than some other varieties.  Second, don't attempt to scoop out all the flesh, down to the skin.  Leave a good 1/4 in. of potato on the skin.  This is the way restaurants do it and generally makes for much better results.

text:
I used very very large russet baking potatoes for this recipe. Perfect.  I also added 4 oz. of cream cheese to this recipe and used packaged Hormel REAL Crumbled Bacon to save time.  I made and stuffed these potatoes in the morning and refrigerated them, then cooked then at 350 for about 35-40 mins.  Sooooo I guess these can be done ahead of time which makes them even better!!  Certainly not a low-fat recipe - especially after I added the cream cheese, but wonderful.  My family and friends loved it. I love the idea that they can be done ahead of time. Hope someone finds this helpful. *******************************
Update:  So here it is 2013! I can’t believe I wrote the above post in 2004.   I’m still making this recipe! I got the “do-ahead” instructions down and thought I should update this post.  
You can make this dish a day or two ahead of time.  Do not bake it.  After topping with bacon and cheese, just cover with plastic wrap and put in the refrigerator.  Remember the directions do not consider the refrigerator factor so it will increase baking  time.  However, to help take it of the refrigerator and let it sit out at room temperature for about one hour or a little longer. This will cut down on baking time. Bake about 1.25 hours but watch them – you want them heated through and the cheese lightly browned.  
Freezing:   Freeze prior to baking.  Tip:  flash freeze them so they’re in individual servings.

text:
I've made these twice and they are always a hit! I read the other reviews and here's what I suggest:
1) I use the largest potatoes I can find. It doesn't matter if you cook them at 350,400 whatever. The point is to cook them until a knife will go easily through them. It usually takes me an hour and a half. I also wrap mine in foil with a teeny bit of butter and salted. 
2) I also mash mine with about 1/2 pkg of cream cheese. I just happen to really like cream cheese. :-)
3) I mix the bacon in the potato mixture. I don't mess with topping it usually. 
4) The easiest way to get the mixture into the shells is to spoon it all into a large Ziploc bag, snip a corner off the bag, and squeeze it into the shells. No mess! 
5) If you're in a hurry, you can also broil the potatoes until the tops start to brown. Quicker than baking.
6) These freeze really well wrapped in plastic wrap and then aluminum foil.

text:
I have been making this same recipe for years with one exception.  I make them with mini red skinned potatoes.  Here's how: cut the mini potatoes in half length-wise, toss in a bowl with a few tablespoons of olive oil to coat and bake them at 425 degrees, cut side down for about 25 minutes.  After they have cooled for about 10 minutes you can scoop out the flesh with a mellon baller.  Then follow the rest of the steps of this recipe.  Using the mini potatoes is faster than larger ones (use as many mini potatoes as you think it would take to equal four large potatoes, usually about 12 for the size I buy)because they bake so fast and they make perfect sized finger foods.  Great for a barbeque when none of the other food requires a fork!  No matter how many of these I make I never have leftovers!

text:
Everyone enjoyed at Christmas dinner.  Tips: Next time, I'd reduce green onions in the stuffing mix and would add a little finely chopped bacon.
How to get perfect potato "shells" - bake potatoes in oven (if you wrap in foil when you bake, don't do so), allow to cool about 10 minutes, and slice in half longwise as recipe suggests. Then, use knife to gentle slice around the edge of the potato as you would when cutting a grapefruit (leave about 1/8 inch of flesh and skin to give the shell some weight). Then, slice the flesh of the potato almost to the bottom in quarters. Use the knife from the center to loosen the quarters from the shell. This should leave you with a firm shell to stuff.

text:
After reading the reviews I couldn't wait to make these potatoes and once I did, I was more than pleased!  Even the pickiest of eaters loved these twice baked potatoes, sour cream and all! I received compliments for three days afterwards.  So simple and fun to make... I made them the day before and threw them in the oven for 35 minutes straight from the fridge (topped with extra cheese of course) and they were perfect!  After initially baking the potatoes I took other's advice and put them in the freezer to cool-and scooping was so easy. Would definitely recommend adding the sour cream a little bit at a time to get the desired texture that you want. I can't wait for another cookout so I can make these wonderful potatoes again!

text:
These are great, and one of those dishes that if you're going to go through the trouble, you might as well make a huge batch and freeze them. They're a perfect "freezer-to-oven" meal, here's how:
1. I typically triple the recipe, bake the potatoes and stuff them, but do not put them in the oven a second time.
2. Put stuffed potatoes in a single row on a baking sheet and put in the freezer for an hour until solid.
3. Now you can freeze them without having them stick together.
4. Cook frozen, 375 for 45-50 minutes. 
I'm having a baby in two months, and having a lot of these in the freezer ready to cook will make my life so much easier!

text:
For those of you who find the mixture a bit runny, I suggest you hold off on adding the milk until the end, and add just enough to get the right consistancy. Also, I don't cut the potatoes in half. I use 1 potato per person, and cut off the top 1/3, and use only the bottom 2/3. The shell hold up better, and the presentation looks much better. This method also allows you to use smaller potatoes as well.

text:
Delicious!  This was my first time making any kind of twice-baked potato and I was half expecting it to be a messy disaster.  But these turned out perfectly!  I used large russet baking potatoes and did what another reviewer suggested - baked them for an hour at 400 degrees with no foil on my upper oven rack.  About 30 minutes in, I put the bacon on a cookie sheet, placed it on the lower rack and cooked it for about 15 minutes.  Then I pulled it out to let it cool so I could crumble it later.    When creating the filling, I used a melon baller to remove the inner part of the potato.  I also put in a few dashes of both garlic and onion powder.  I first mixed everything but the milk and then added it a little at a time until it reached the consistency I wanted.  I also stirred bacon into the whole filling instead of just sprinkling it on top.  I served these with steak and salad.  My boyfriend ate three and skipped his salad because he didn't want to "waste the room" in his stomach with salad when he could have one of these potatoes instead.  :D

First off...what are people thinking to undercook the potato and then use instant potato to fix it, and then rate it??!!  Obviously, cooking time will vary!  If the potato isn't done...keep cooking it.  Why would anyone bother to rate it when they completely changed the recipe?

I didn't think I could make them ahead and have then turn out that good, but they were even better than the night I made them!  Really good recipe.  A definite crowd pleaser.  Thanks so much.

text:
This recipe was a hit at my dinner party and took so much pressure off me by allowing me to make it the day before and just heat it before the dinner.  I used ideas from prior reviews which were really helpful: (1)wash, dry, rub outside of potatoes with oil, then microwave them for about 15 minutes, then bake 50-60 minutes, (2)use fat free sour cream, (3) add 4 oz fat-free or reduced fat cream cheese, (4)use real bacon bits from jar, (5) use reduced fat shredded cheese, (6) roast garlic in oven with potatoes and squeeze into potato mix. I had to heat potatoes for about 45-50 minutes from refrigerated state. Everyone loved them!  YUM!

These were AMAZING. My boyfriend and I made these for the next two days after because they were so good. 
I did cheat a little. I put them in the microwave for 3 minutes first and then was able to have them in the oven for 30 min at 370 instead of an hour. Saved a lot of time and tasted just as good! I do think that next time I make them I will broil them for a couple minutes at the end to get the skins a bit more crispy. Also used chives instead of green onions and yum yum!

text:
Awesome!  I prepared these a couple of days ahead and froze them.  I was so happy because freezing the did not change the taste of the potato.  I made them clear up to the point of stuffing them but did not bake them.  I also added the bacon to the filling mixture.  I placed them on a cookie sheet and froze the until solid.  I then wrapped them in tinfoil, placed in a Ziploc freezer bag and froze until needed.  When I was ready for them, I took off the foil, placed on a cookie sheet and baked at 375 for 55 minutes.  I put the cheese on for the last 10 minutes and topped with extra bacon and green onions when they were done, a huge hit at my house!

text:
I have been making Twice Baked Potatoes this way for years.  Instead of green onions, I grate an onion and use that.  After scooping out the flesh of the potato, I put the skins back into the oven so they dry out a little more.  I usually make 10 baking potatoes, place the ones I'm not using on a cookie sheet and freeze them.  When they are frozen, wrap individually in freezer bags.  They will last about 3 months.  When ready to use, defrost and then bake at 350 until hot.

I love this recipe and have cooked it for years (maybe not this one, but my version, which is quite close), the difference I do is adding the cream cheese (my rule of thumb is 1 tablespoon of cream cheese for each potato), but also, after scooping out the flesh, return the skins to the oven and bake for another 10-15 minutes until golden brown in the inside, then finish as normal... yummy for the tummy :O)

city:

region:

text:
I love potatoes made like this!! ive been making them for years. the good thing about these is the recipe is totally customizable. my fave combo is chaddar cheese,cheez whiz,butter,garlic,chives,sour cream,bacon and cut up broccoli...mmm.my husband enjoys a "jalepeno popper"version.there really is no wrong way to fill them!
heres a quick tip to SAVE time. take the potato and cut a circular/oval shape in the skin on the top of the raw potato(do not remove this chunk of potato) within the circle, cut deep lines(dont cut thru the bottom of the potato)instead of baking, you can microwave them for 10 mins(give or take depending on # of potatos and size).test for doneness with a fork,if still hard return to microwave for 1-2 mins at a time.after theyre cooked put them in the freezer for 10 mins.once theyre cooled you can scrape the circle of skin off the top with a spoon,and it leaves you with a perfect shaped hole to scoop the potato out. to avoid tearing the skin, leave about 1/4 inch of potato remaining.mix the scooped out potato with the filling, and top with a dab of butter or a slice of real cheddar cheese, bake in the oven at 500(or broil works too) until theyre crispy and brown on top. hope you find this useful!

text:
This is so simple and yet so delicious!  My only change is that I rub olive oil on the outside and sprinkle with course sea salt and cracked black pepper before baking. You can use a little less milk or add a little cream cheese if you are worried about the mixture being too thin, but I have never had any issues.

text:
Great recipe. I have made these for years, using evaporated milk or buttermilk, garlic powder, mayo and sour cream, chives, real butter then scooping them out and leave about 1/4 inch on the skins for support as you refill. Then I top with cheese and paprika. I wrap them individually and freeze or vaccum pack them for future use. I do a whole 5 lb. bag at once. city:

None
text:
Easier/Faster Version!! Bake your potatoes at 500 degrees for one hour
When done and waiting to cool a tad bit 
Scoop a bunch of shredded cheese, real bacon bits (from a jar lol), chives, a big dollop of butter, and sour cream mixed with some Hidden Valley Ranch Dip packet into a large (gallon) zip lock bag.
Cut your potatoes in half long ways
and scoop out the center being careful not to tear the potato skins.
Mix into the baggie with all of your fixins and add a little heavy whipping cream. All you have to do is squish the bag untill all of your lumps are gone! Then cut one corner off the baggie and twist into pastry bag shape and squeeze into your hollow potato skins.
Bake for another 20 minutes (or untill lightly golden on top) at 350 degrees.
Done and YUMMMMM!!!!

10295343
Display Name:
Erin Michelle Highbaugh

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1886978.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a really great recipe for restaurant style twice baked potatoes.  Be aware that YOU HAVE TO USE YOUR PERSONAL JUDGEMENT ON THE MEASUREMENTS OF INGREDIENTS based on the size of your potatoes.  Every time you buy potatoes, they will be different sizes (even potatoes in the same bag are different).  I try to buy the very large "baker" Russet potatoes (many grocery stores put two or four in a wrapped container and label them "bakers"), but the 5 or 10 lb bagged Russets will work just as well.  If your potatoes are small, you can always use 6 or 8 potatoes instead of 4 - believe me, they will be eaten!

When adding the liquid/soft ingredients, do NOT dump the entire amounts in all at once.  Only add half, then mix with potatoes and add more if needed to get the correct consistency.  If your potatoes are on the small side, and you add the full amount of soft/liquid ingredients, you will end up with a runny soup.

When scooping out the insides, I use a spoon, and after the first large scoop, I just scoop a LITTLE at a time to make sure I don't tear the potato.  You can always take a little more potato out if you go slow.

Some people have complained the recipe is too bland.  I add about a teaspoon of garlic powder and a pinch of cayenne pepper to the mashed potato mix, and I sprinkle some paprika on the top with the green onions.  I also add salt and pepper to taste (usually 1 - 1 1/2 teaspoons of each).

All and all, this is a great basic recipe that's easy to customize!

text:
Comfort food crowd pleaser.  Can't go wrong.  I've made these several times and agree with others that making the filling up ahead of time makes them taste better, and it makes it easier on you if this is part of a large feed.  I also doubled the bacon.  I put 8 slices in with the filling, and then 8 slices on top.  I also added garlic powder to the filling.  If you use large baking potatoes, its going to take more like 1 15 min to 1 30 min till they are done.  Also, rub the taters in oil and wrap in foil for baking.  Don't get greedy and try to get every little ounce of tater flesh out of the skin.  Leave some around edges.  Otherwise, your taters will fall apart and not be able to stand up the chunky yummy filling.  Sometimes I use the small red potatoes which is nice because lighter eaters aren't too intimidated to put one on their plate.  If you use large bakers, the portions are just huge.

text:
These were good. I read a lot of the reviews and have the following tips: based on the size of your potatoes you will have to adjust the amount of milk, sour cream etc that you will need to use, so that the potatoes are not too thin. You are basically making mashed potatoes so you have to do it to taste and not follow the recipe so literally in terms of amounts to use. I used a melon baller to scoop out my potatoes and this helped to keep the potatoes in tact.  Also, I tried to make these a little healthier by: using low fat sour cream, non fat 1/2 and 1/2, turkey bacon and using less cheese than called for. I also greatly reduced the green onions and didnt include them in my stuffing but sprinked them sparinly on top.

These are soooo good, my finace gets all giddy whenever I make these! When I'm trying to get something other than beer & red meat into him, I also add some tuna in there - it might sound wierd, but it tastes great! I also found that brushing the potatoes with a little olive oil and then sprinkling a bit of salt, pepper or other seasoning on them (rosemary works well) before baking makes for a really crisp, savory skin that is a little easier to scoop out. Thanks for a great recipe!

These were absolutely fantastic!  My fiance and I ate them for dinner last night.  We also cooked hamburger steak with onions and gravy also from this site, and they both turned out wonderfully!  The only change I made was I mixed the bacon and chives with the potatoes, and I baked all at once. (This is the 15 minute baking time).  One more quick note, the time was off a bit. That would be the only complaint I would have, although, everyone should try these atleast once!  I will surely be making these again... thank you so much for the recipe!!!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
These potatoes are fantastic!  I have made them according to the recipe, which in my opinion is still a 4-5 star recipe.  However, instead of sour cream, I stumbled across using 0% fat plain greek yogurt (which is thick and adds a really nice tangy flavour to the potatoes) one day when I had run out of sour cream.  The yogurt replacement has become our standard now!  I also usually add only 2 tbsp of butter and also add in 1-2 tbsp of minced, dried onion to the mashed potato filling (because my hubby can't eat green onions).  Chicken bacon (instead of regular bacon) is also good on top of the potatoes.  However, we have had it regular bacon, too, and both ways makes for an extremely yummy potato!  Thanks ponygirl!

text:
I have been making these delicious twice baked taters for years! I do a few things different though, I bake my potatoes without the foil on 400 degrees for about an hour, this causes the skin to harden and makes it easier to scoop all of the potato out and makes a nice secure boat to put ingredients back in. I also don't use any milk and add some season salt as well. My family would eat these every night if I made them! They are the best.

region:

country:
None
text:
I have made these numerous times, and they always turn out perfect! I get so many requests for these potatoes that I don't even have to look at the recipe anymore...I know it by heart! I read some reviews where the readers say the potatoes are runny. This has never happened to me before, but I can only think of two things to suggest. First, use Yukon Gold baking potatoes. They are meater and hold there substance better than others. And second, I always make these ahead of time and place them in the refrigerator until I am ready to bake them for the addtional 15 minutes. This may help keep them from being too runny. All I can say is bake and enjoy!

I made this w/ red potatoes , that was all I had so I baked 2 of them took filling out of both put in bowl.. Kept the shell of the larger red potaoes. I had to use bacon bits because I was out of bacon.. I used Wisconsin Extra Sharp White Cheddar cheese & diced up couple slices of yellow onion.. got my blender out mixed everything together.. OMG you can lick the blender handles I filled back up the potato shell it over flowed some so I wrapped extra aluminum foil to support hold the extra filling... WHEN IT WAS DONE, THE BEST BAKED POTATO I ever had.. I didnt ad topping at all except the butter because I forgot to mix it in. If  you like potatoes this is the best way to eat them.. text:
Wow! The only thing I did differently was put some finely diced garlic in but other than that is was perfect! I also Roast my potatoes at 350 for one hour after i lather them in EVOO and Kosher salt. Do not wrap in foil. Just poke some holes in the spud with a fork(about 8-10 times, all around) then the oil and salt. Throw right on a rack in your oven towards the top and cook for 1 hour. Perfect every time and that way you have a great seasoned skin that you can eat as well. I also did not use bacon. Didn't need it.

text:
OH MY GOSHHH! Honestly, a really great recipe. Just made it for my boyfriend and I. I served it with ribeye steaks and ceasar salad. As a college student, I enjoy thinking outside of the box and refraining from eating ramen every night or going to chipotle so this was a great change. I tweaked the recipe just a little but no major changes. I halved the recipe because there was only two of us and it was more than enough. I rubbed the potatoes with olive oil and salt and then microwaved them for three minutes to cut on time. It only took thirty minutes in the oven. I cut back on the sour cream and the green onions and mixed some of the bacon in before rebaking. Turned out AMAZING. My boyfriend is a really picky eater and he loved it. His exact words "I guess I like potatoes now?" But then again when steak is the main dish he thinks everything else on the table is gold.

text:
Wonderful! Just don't add so much milk. I'd suggest only adding a little bit of milk as you mix. You're going to find that the butter and the sour cream make it creamy enough and if you were to actually add all the milk the recipe calls for you'll have a too runny mixture. I skipped adding the bacon and didn't have green onions but found adding some onion powder was just as tastey. This is the 2nd time I've made these in the last month. They also freeze up well. I wrap in plastic wrap and then put in a freezer bag. Easy to pull out and microwave for a quick side later on.

text:
I have been making these for years, I suggest that you do not wrap your potatoes in foil instead put them on a metal skewer ( more than 1 potatoe on each), then put them in the oven.  They will cook faster and the skins will be easier to handle. I use fat free sour cream, low fat cheese, and only add the milk if I need them thinner.  If you like Jalapeno peppers you can chopper them up and add to mixture, or just add them to the top before cooking.  These are a favorite in my house, I always make extras so when someone wants a snack they just grab one and pop it in the microwave.  (You can also add a little garlic and herbs the them, add just about anything you like and they are great)

text:
I have been making my twice baked potatoes with these same ingrediants for years (although I just eye ball the ingrediants) and they are a hit.  A tip for spooning out the potato flesh... Hold the halved potato in your palm using a pot holder or folded towel to protect your hand from being burned.  Gently scoop out the flesh with a teaspoon being careful not to scoop too deep and tear the skin.

text:
Less would be more!  These had way too much butter, sour cream, bacon, onions, and cheese!  The only thing I changed with the recipe was I cut the milk back to 1/4 cup and then added another tbsp after it was all mixed.  Judging on the consistency, I would not add that extra tbsp and stick to the 1/4 c.  The other thing I changed, was I brushed on olive oil and sprinkled coarse salt on the potatoes skins before putting on cookie sheet to bake.  My potatoes did cook perfectly after 60 minutes.  My skins were soft.  I carefully scooped out flesh (leaving a good 1/4 inch on skin) and they stayed intact.  Next time I make these, I will probably cut everything back (except potatoes) to 3/4 the amount and then go from there.

Display Name:
SUNDOWNER02

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make these all the time with the following options to slim them down and speed them up: 1) I cook my potatoes in the microwave until almost done, then remove and wrap in a kitchen towel to let them steam the rest of the way.  I also cook one additional potato (usually a smaller one) in order to have a nice heaping serving.  2)  I saute medium diced onion and peppers (orange, yellow red are pretty) in a little olive oil to start and then chicken broth to finish up (cook till almost dry). 3)  I add dill, basil, oregano (whichever you prefer best) to the onion mixture as it sautes.  4)  I add half a package of lipton onion soup mix to the potato mixture. 5)  I use low fat sour cream and enough butter to make it taste yummy. 6)  I use the precooked bacon that has been crisped up in the microwave. 7)  I don't usually need milk because of the wetness of the sauteed veggies.  8)  And the cheese and green onions put them over the top.  They can be very fast with these shortcuts and always a hit.

text:
I have been making this for years and it is always a hit.  I microwave the spuds, cut in half, & remove the "meat". I spread butter in the potato halfs & crisp in the toaster oven or oven.  This makes for a nice crispy skin. While the spuds are in the oven I mix the "meat" & all the other yummy ingredients.  When spuds are crisp I fill the spuds, top with cheese & back and broil.  I cannot wait to have these on Friday.  Happy Holidays everyone.

text:
I have been making 2X baked for years, without a recipe. This recipe had all of the same ingredients I use, so decided to give it a try.  This recipe had all of the right measurements. I usually throw  the ingredients into a bowl and make adjustments as I go. Measurements made the process much faster.  I use light sour cream and 2% cheddar for the potato mixture and the fattening stuff on top because 2% doesn't melt the same. I use the bacon peices Costo sells in a bag and crisp them in the microwave on a paper towel (we like our bacon crspy).  *Note* 1/2 cup bacon bits = 8 slices fried bacon.   I tripled the recipe and will put them in the freezer. Twice baked freeze great. My huband and daughter, that have a both have gift of never gaining weight, will snack on them daily until gone. I will need to practice a lot of restraint.

text:
These potatoes have become a holiday tradition around our home. I have found that the following substitutions produce the same oohs and ahs at the table, with less guilt: use low-fat shredded cheddar cheese, use 1/2 non-fat plain yogurt and 1/2 low-fat sour cream in place of the 1 cup of regular sour cream, use half the bacon (the flavor is still there!) 

I also use 1/2 chives and 1/2 green onions for a nice flavor addition.

Enjoy!

text:
Great recipe!! I followed this recipe to the exact ingredient and they turned out great. If you use a large enough size baking potato it will not be soupy and if you bake your potatoes unwrapped on the oven rack the skin will be tough enough to scoop the pulp out. Be sure you pierce the potato with a fork or sharp knife or it will explode in the oven. I know from experience. LOL These potatoes are better than any twice baked potato I have had in any restaurant.

text:
The only reason I gave this recipe high marks is because I had to "fix" it and then it was great.  Unfortunately, the "large" potatoes I cooked for 1 hr at 350 degrees were way underdone.  I guess it was my fault for not checking their doneness before I cut them in half.   1 hr at 400 or 425 degrees was needed.  The author must have used much smaller potatoes than mine.  Other recipes for twice baked potatoes call for either 1 or 1-1/2 hr at the higher temperature.

text:
This is one of my favorite comfort foods. I took off a star because when I measure according to the recipe, the mixture is too runny for my tastes. I cut down on the sour cream. 

This freezes well, too. After refilling the potato skins, I put the potatoes on a baking sheet in the freezer until they're solid, then I wrap them in foil and package in a gallon-sized ziplock bag. Then I thaw as many as I want and bake once thawed.

text:
This was my first time making these, I always add or subtract a little to my liking and consistency; I forgot to buy green onions, so we did without it. I made them the night before Easter, I was feeding 10 people and had no room in my fridge to keep them overnight so I baked the potatoes and scooped out the middle and put it in a covered bowl, then covered the hollowed potatoes as well and left everything on the counter overnight without adding any of the dairy products that would spoil. I warmed the flesh the next day in the microwave, heated the milk and added all other ingredients. I used a pastry pouch with a decorating tip to make them a little more fancy, then put them in the oven while the meat was resting on the counter. They were a hit!

text:
well... I don't know what the deal is but a potato never gets done in one hour at 350. Unless they are really small ones. I bake them at 400 or even 450 for an hour. Also: I don't use a hand mixer for potatoes: they can end up with a glue-like consistency. Read a good cookbook like Joy of Cooking and they will validate this. Use a good old potato masher and the potatoes come out the perfect consistency.

It could be a 5 star by changing the following things:

1. Switching out milk for evaporated milk. This changes the consistency to more creamy and less watery. 
2. Try mixing 4 tbs Ranch dressing (or to taste) for added sweet flavor- so delicious!

My mother n'law famously makes these with the evaporated milk and ranch dressing. It's always a hit at every party and people- EVERYONE- loves them.

Another idea for the potato skin staying intact, in addition to using baking potatoes, grease the potatoes with a little shortening (I also add a little kosher salt on top of the shortening). The potato skin will be nice and crisp when done baking and the potato flesh will be much easier to scoop out.

text:
I modified this recipe also.  Omitted the sour cream, and added, Softened Cream Cheese with Chives a couple heaping spoonfuls, thus allowing me to not add the milk, additionally I added garlic powder, however next time will use fresh minced.  I baked the potatoes in the morning and let the skins sit on a rack covered, while my Spare ribs baked slowly in the oven.  The last hour I pulled out the ribs transferred to a Slow Cooker to finish on low and then assembled the potatoes, topping with green onions, and Cheddar Cheese.

dateLastModified:

userID:
5416546
Display Name:
Rhonda Mai
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
12
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6343302.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Big hit at the dinner table!!!  My family has already requested that I add this recipe to our Christmas menu.  Here’s what I did   •Used all the ingredients but eyeballed the amounts to get firm mix.   •Baked 8 very large potatoes but only stuffed 6 •Used a hot pad when holding potatoes and scooping insides out.    •Microwave bacon and added it into the mash mix instead of on top.   •Put most the cheese into the mix and sprinkled just a little on top.    When finished the potatoes were rounder and way prettier than the picture shown.  I had 2 leftovers that were just as wonderful reheated in the microwave the next day.     Some of the reviews people had trouble cooking the potatoes.  Don’t follow these directions word for word when it comes to baking potatoes.  If this is your first time or you are unsure how to bake a potatoe, I suggest researching online how to do this instead of following these directions.

text:
Very good! I made it healthier by doing the following: Used turkey bacon (and mixed it into the filling), halved the butter, used light sour cream (half of what was called for) and a little less milk. I also didn't have green onions, so I sauteed vidalia onion in the turkey "grease" and some olive oil and added that to the filling. I made in the morning, put in the fridge, and baked at 350 for 30 minutes (adding cheese to the top after 10 minutes). These were excellent! :)

text:
We all loved these very much! I was told these are better than the ones served in a restaurant. Only thing I did different, and I'm glad I did, is I used 5 potatoes, but only stuffed 4 of them. I just used the flesh from the fifth potato so I had plenty of filling to stuff the shells nice and full, so the appearance was mounded. If you don't do this, I do believe they will not seem very stuffed, but they would be fine. I just used the other 2 halves to make potato skins as a little appetizer. We thought everything went together very well, perfect amounts of ingredients. I pretty much added a little more of the ingredients listed to the filling since I did use an extra potato.  I wrapped the potatoes in foil to bake, and I let them cool over an hour before scooping them out. I didn't have any problems with the skin/shell  breaking at all, it's much easier to do this when they are really cooled down. This recipe is going to be used very often. Thank you :)

text:
So yummy!  I made these tonight with the Blackened Chicken recipe from this site and it was a winning combo.  The only reason I am reluctant to give this recipe 5 stars is because I feel the baking temp is incorrect.  Baked potatoes are usually done at 400 degrees, so that is what I baked my 8 medium sized potatoes at and they were perfect in 45 minutes.  I did have some difficulty scooping out the middle of the potatoes without completely destroying the skins, though, so perhaps baking them longer at a lower temp makes this easier? (but I doubt it)  I also didn't whip my filling entirely, because I wanted to keep some texture in there.  If you use the mixer for too long or at too high of a speed the sour cream will break down too much and could turn your filling runny.  Mine was perfect and my family gobbled these up.  Thanks for a great recipe! (but try baking at 400 )

text:
The whole family really liked these potatoes. We used a little less sour cream and about 1/2 of the milk listed (used half and half in place of milk). The potatoes used were really big so that added a few minutes to the initial baking time. After baking and stuffing, placed them on a baking sheet and covered and refrigerated until about 30 minutes before dinner. Baked at 375 covered for about 25 minutes and then uncovered, sprinkled cheese, bacon and scallions on top and baked additional 6 -7 minutes and they were perfect. We will make these again and again. Thanks for sharing!

I've seen HW (Happywife) rec these time and time again on the RE.  However, I've never used a recipe for twice bakeds...I just dice/chop/plop and mash...a pinch here, a dash there-you get the picture.  My FIL requested these for his bday dinner and I decided to give this recipe a whirl.  I'm so glad I did!  We all LOVED them.  I think the green onion really makes them pop.  I followed the recipe, though I did have to nuke the potatoes a bit as they weren't done after an hour and a half in the oven.  I made them the night before and refrigerated them before the second bake the next day.  I was using the oven at 425, so I baked them for about 15 min at that temp, covered for the first 10.  THANKS for a great recipe, PONYGIRL!

We make twice-baked potatoes as a vegetarian option on the cruise boat I cook for (Without the meat, of course). text:
Great with BBQ steak.  Made these a day ahead, and refrigerated them covered tightly with plastic wrap.  On serving day, take them out of the frig about one hour ahead to begin to come to room temperature.  Place a rack in a shallow baking pan lined with foil.  Preheat oven to 400 and heat potatoes about 20 minutes.  The skins stay crispier that way, a tasty counterpoint to the creamy filling.  I used one more bacon slice and about four green onions, which was just to my taste.  Very well received by guests. A delicious recipe.  Thanks.

text:
I have tried this recipe twice.  The first time I had not much success because of the time for baking the potatoes.
The second time they turned out great.  I combined cheese, green onion, sour cream, milk, garlic, salt and pepper.  Five minutes before serving I sprinkled extra cheese and a small amount of paprika before serving and broiled them. This gave the potatoes great coloring and the melted cheese was yummy!
Will definitely be used for company with many of my future meals.
Thank you!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/159735.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make these all the time! I've used a couple short cuts to save time. First, I "bake" them in the microwave for the first bake, that really cuts down on bake time. It only takes about 10 min. to cook 4 baking potatos instead of an hour. I let the oven pre-heat while the potatos are "baking." It's important to use a potholder when handling the hot potatos. Since the skin comes out a little softer when prepared in the microwave, it's important to leave a good 1/4" skin when scooping out the insides. Second, I buy pre-cooked bacon. I follow the rest of the directions for mixing the filling and bake the second time in the oven. They always come out perfect. My kids actually prefer them cooked in the micro first because the skin isn't quite so tough. I hope this helps some time savy cooks save some time!

these were good. i rolled the potatoes in some olive oil and sea salt before baking. then i just placed them on the top rack w/ a roasting pan on the bottom to catch the potato ooze. this gives the skin a really great texture. i had to use bacon bits because i was out of bacon and they turned out pretty good. i just mixed them in instead of putting them on top. i think next time i make these i will broil them after filling them because i like the tops to brown a bit and they didnt.

Display Name:
MrsSkiing

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making twice baked potatoes and the recipe was easy to prepare and came out wonderful.  I fully prepped this meal in the morning and stored them in the fridge until it was time to bake them for 30 min. at 350 degrees.  I baked 8 medium-large potatoes, but only prepared 7 halves.  I wanted the potatoes to be over filled with the potato mixture.  Allow the potatoes to cool slightly before slicing in half and then allow them to further cool before scooping out the potato with a teaspoon.  I left a thin layer of potato in the skin and as a result had no problem with the skin staying intact.  For the filling I used some snipped chives instead of green onions and I mixed ¾ of both the chives and the bacon into the filling.  I used fat free half and half instead of plain milk and also added a ½ cup of reduced fat cream cheese to mixture for taste and texture.  Make sure to mix in the milk and sour cream gradually as mixing until the desired texture in reached.  I ended up not needing all the milk and sour cream.  I stuffed the skin initially with a spoon and then piped on the top layer with a pastry bag fitted with large tip to get a finished look and topped with shredded cheese and the rest of the chives and bacon.  I will be making these potatoes again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These. Are. Amazing.

A few things: I will NEVER understand why people bake their potatoes in the oven!!! I popped mine in the microwave (three large potatoes) and in 20 minutes, they were perfectly tender. Waited for them to cool, and used a serrated knife to slice them lengthwise. Be very careful while scooping out the insides - give yourself plenty of time so you're not rushed. The mixture looked/tasted great even before it went back into the potatoes. You don't even really need to measure: put ingredients in according to your own tastes. I (accidentally) left out the butter which cut tons of fat while the sour cream made it just as creamy. When everything was done, they looked so impressive: very colorful, flavorful... these would be perfect for entertaining (esp. with steak in the summer) and they also reheat well. Could make a lunch of 'em the next day!! Just perfect.

I only modified this recipe to make it a little more healthy, because it is just about perfect! I completely omitted the milk and reduce the butter to 2 tablespoons and used light sour cream and 2% shredded cheddar cheese.  I also added a little garlic powder along with the salt and pepper for extra flavor.

text:
If your trying to eat low fat, low calarie, this is not the thing to be eating, but boy are they worth straying off a diet for. My daughter doesn't like potatoes as a rule, but she really liked these, which was thrilling.  As others suggested, I rubbed the skins with olive oil, and the outsides turned out soft and perfect.  I also added some regular onion to the flesh, and didn't have green onion, so I used chives.  They were easier to make than I thought they would be, and they are rich, so a little goes a long way. With 4 kids and a husband, it's almost impossible to find something that they all like, but these were a hit with everyone!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-12-24T17:41:17.543
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
1193012
Display Name:
azstacy09
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
31
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making these for 30 years, in one form or another. For a good skin, rub the potato with oil (any kind), and cover with salt. Do NOT poke holes. Bake in oven at a higher temp (400) until done. This gives the potato a very nice flavorful, hard skin and creates a fluffier inside. I like to mix bacon and green onions in the mix to meld all flavors. And just smash for a chunkier consistency. To the mix, I add about 2 T of horseradish (medium), a few dashes of hot sauce and a little Worchestershire to kick it up. For the topping, I mix shredded cheese with a little Panko or bread crumbs and some melted butter. After baking for the time suggested, broil them for a minute or so to get a nice crust on top (watch them!) Delish!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-08-17T17:10:54.73
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
2319534
Display Name:

text:
I had two leftover baked potatoes, so I cut them in half, scooped out the flesh, added butter and cheese and bacon bits, and nuked. (I didn't add salt since I'd coated the potatoes in EVOO and kosher salt while they baked.) Once everything was warm, I added the sour cream and put the mixture back in the skins and baked. Great way to stretch 2 potatoes to feed 4 people...keeper!

None
text:
Amazing recipe. Few minor changes. Used chives instead of green onions,  bacon bits instead of real bacon (much easier and still so yummy) and I incorporated the bacon,  chives, cheese and butter all together with the potato flesh. Also be careful not to add to much milk as the mixture will be very runny just add a little at a time until you get a thick mashed potato like consistency.  I placed the mixture in a big zip lock bag, snipped off the corner and filled the skins. No mess! I added a bit of cheese and bacon on top when baking for the second time. Soooooo delish!

text:
Yummy but we veered somewhat afield by picking and choosing changes made by other reviewers. Microwaved extra large russet potatoes for 8 minutes at 70%, turning once mid way through, and then baking in oven for 1 hour at 375° F. For the stuffing mixture, added 4 ounces cream cheese and chopped broccoli florets, subbed turkey bacon bits for pork bacon, and reduced sour cream to 1/2 cup and reduced milk, pouring as needed to make a creamy consistency. Very good recipe PONYGIRL64, and thanks for sharing.

text:
Good recipe - thanks!  A variation we've followed for a few years is to mix in a cup or so of brie instead of the cheddar in the "mashed" step - adds a great creaminess.  Also, we spray a little cooking oil and powdered garlic into the potato shells and pop them back into the oven for 5-10 minutes, to "harden" the shell just slightly. (Sometimes we'll make them a little more crunchy, depending on our mood.) That will combat the tendency others mentioned for the skins to come apart when stuffing.

text:
I've made these for years - both at home and at the fraternity house where I cook.   Perfect menu item to prepare in advance for larger groups - I often freeze them in ziplock bags or refrigerate on baking sheets depending on how soon I'll use them.   Since I have a prolific herb garden, I much prefer using fresh chives in season to the green onions  - just snip with scissors.  For great flavor you can use a combo of softened cream cheese and ranch dressing in lieu of sour cream/milk/salt/pepper for the same texture.

country:
None
text:
Excellent Recipe! I have made these before, and always make a little more because you can freeze these on a baking sheet in the freezer, then put them in a freezer bag for later. Simply put the filled freezer bag in water to get most of the air out and then take a straw and stick though the last amount of opening in the seal; then suck the remainder of the air out. These will keep in the freezer for up to 4-5+ months. I always keep precooked bacon in the freezer too for salads and anything else. If you are going to heat your oven for an hour, you might as well do as many as you like for lunches, dinners and snacks. YUMMY!! (Don't waste your money on "premade" when you can make these for a little of nothing with ingredients on hand. :))

text:
These are absolutely delicious.  I wanted to a nice hot meal for camping, so I did all the prep work at home and then wrapped the stuffed potatoes individually in tin foil for the second round of "baking"...we placed them on the coals of the fire for about 10 minutes and they came out quite nicely!  Make sure you bring tongs if you choose to cook them this way, because the foil will be too hot to touch.  A unique, satisfying dish for camping - thank you for the recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome recipe - here's how I reduced prep time and added punch...
Microwave (yes microwave potatoes on high for 3 min. rotate(flip), 2 min more) remove and place in oven or toaster oven at 450 for 15 minutes. Potatoes are cooked perfectly with a firm skin for scooping.
Now scoop out and make your favorite mashed potato recipe.
The PUNCH --- blend in smoked Gouda and some cheddar, your bacon bits - cooked from scratch of course as noted above and the rest - sour cream, milk or heavy cream, melted butter, salt pepper, etc.
Scoop in to skins and top with more Gouda and cheddar. Place in oven or toaster oven (300) for another 10 minutes. DONE. green onions or chives on the side....
You can make these unbelievable twice baked in 30 minutes - I know, I do it all the time and my family and guests cant get enough!

text:
Awesome dish. I made these for Thanksgiving dinner and they came out perfect, everybody loved them. I'm on a lactose/dairy free diet currently, but made an exception for Thanksgiving. But that doesn't mean I skimped out, I substituted as much as possible. For those of you who are trying to make these but still stay on the relatively healthy side here's what I subbed; 1 c Lactose Free Sour Cream, 1/2 C Original Almond Milk, 4 Tbsp of coconut butter, 1 Tsp Sea Salt. Taste was excellent! Remember that since you are adding ingredients to the scooped out potato, you will have extra filling. You can fill the inside of 5 - 6 Potatos even if you follow the recipe on the bottom exactly, that's what happened to me.

userID:
2655531
Display Name:
Clueless Cook
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this recipe for several years and it is great!!  I've made it using large baking potatoes or using small (even tiny sometimes) red potatoes to make appetizers at parties.  These are always a hit.  I use a hotter oven (around 400 degrees) and place my potatoes right on the rack.  Also, I always mix the cheese, bacon and green onions in with the potato mixture rather than just sprinkling on top.  Also, as with most recipes, I probably throw in more cheese than the recipe calls for.  (I love cheese!)  Otherwise, I just mix all the ingredients as the recipe says and adjust as needed based on the taste of the mixture.  I always make these the night before (up to the point of putting the potato mixture back inside the skins), which is a great time saver.  Try doing the little potatoes the next time you have a dinner party or even as a side dish at a cookout.  I guarantee they'll be a hit!!

text:
I have been making this for years now, and my family loves these. The only change i have made was i was tired of scooping the potatoes so i just peel, boil and whip this up and put it in a baking dish and throw it in the oven. I know the other way looks pretty, but this way you still get the same great taste and half the work. I also saute my green onions in a little bit of butter of bacon grease.

My mom always made these just from memory and taste, but it's so nice to have something to write down for future use!  The only thing i did differently was to use dried chives because i didn't have fresh.  I also cooked my potatoes in the microwave to save time on the first part.  You have to leave about 1/4 inch on the sides to get a nice bowl for your twice baked filling, over scooping can lead to a floppy bowl.

text:
I actually haven't baked potatoes very often---though I do consider myself a fairly good home chef---and I had trouble with the baking time. I only did two potatoes and after 1:20 they were still crunchy in the middle. Anyway, followed to recipe exactly but used "lite" sour cream (I know...why?), added a couple of cloves of garlic to the filling mix, and used chives instead of green onions. In spite of my potatoes still having some slightly crunchy bits in them, these are delicious. Highly recommended, perfect comfort food. We ate them as a meal, with some steamed broccoli on the side just to help cut some of the richness.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My mom made twice baked potatoes all the time when I was a kid, but her's are much simpler than this!  Basically she bakes the potatoes, like you would if you were baking a baked potato, then scoops out the flesh and mashes them like you would for plain old mashed potatoes -- salt, pepper, butter, and milk -- until they're creamy.  Then scoop back into the skins and bake again until golden brown on top.  No sour cream or cheese or chives or bacon.  They're probably good with all the additions, but when I think of twice baked potatoes, I think of them as just potatoes and not everything else with them!

text:
My daughter always request these. Perfect for entertaining big crowds!  Sometimes I would just make this as mashed potatoes rather than a twice  baked if I have other dishes to make and especially when the oven is being used. I make this stress-free by boiling the potatoes first then mashing the potatoes in a crockpot  the night before.
cover with siran wrap and refridgerate. The following day I mixed all the other ingredients and plugged in the crockpot on low heat for  4-5 hrs. Also, adding cream cheese makes these  even more tastier!

text:
We particularly enjoy eating the skins so with that in mind, here are a couple of extra steps (and calories) I take.  First of course scrub the potatoes before baking.  Once you have scooped out the flesh, brush oil or melted butter inside the shells and pop them back in the oven to crisp up while you prepare the stuffing.  I also use garlic salt rather than plain salt.

Love these! To speed up the baking process I cut my potatos in half and put them cut side down on a baking sheet with some olive oil. Baked at 400 for an hour. text:
Very tasty twice baked potatoes. The only thing is I use russet potatoes instead since the skin is way easier to work with, and I would say is bake them a little longer, an hour and 15 to an hour and a half to really get the russets nice and soft. And DON'T wrap them in foil while baking for the first hour, the skin won't get tough that way and you'll end up tearing the skin.

userID:
735785
Display Name:
June
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
17
favoritesCount:
65
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/15219.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A good basic recipe for twice baked potatoes.  I used three baking potatoes I do not cut my potatoes in half after baking. I take a small sharp knife and cut a oval circle out of the top and then gently slice the top skin off. This gives much more room for stuffing the potatoes and they are more stable when moving from oven to plate. A mini cookie scoop also makes fast and easy work of removing the potatoe.we eat them as a full dinner with a salad.  I always  improvise as I cook.  Mine was the addition of half n half instead of milk and 1/4 stick of butter and kept the sourcream probably  to 2/3 cup I  I never measured just tasted as I added stuff. I used extra sharp cheddar cheese  it adds more flavor.  I added about 1/4 tsp salt. Put about 3 green onions into the potates and around two tablespoons of the bacon as well.  I  used  6 extra thick bacon fryed it  and let it cool so it crumbles chops up nice. I then grated about 1/4 cup more cheese and sliced up one whole green onion  mixed all three together put aside.   I heated the now  stuffed potaoes to a nice hot temp in the microwave  put in the oven 10 minutes opened the oven took the mixture of bacon cheese and onion  that I put aside ealier  onto the top and baked for another 5 minutes until the cheese, onion and bacon melted and was sizzlin hot.  I took the tops if the potatoes skins and made peperoni pizza skins to bake for the kids as a treat. This is a nice fun recipe when you want to splurge.

text:
If this doesn't get a 5 star rating then something had to be done wrong. These are absolutely amazing. My husband drools like a dog when he comes home and finds out we are having these. The bacon is a must have on these. The potato mixture that goes back into the potato "shell" is actually wonderful just by itself for mashed potatoes! Mmmmmm! I did try and "cook" the potatoes in the microwave instead of the oven for 10-15 minutes but the microwave makes the "shell" too soft and it tears while scooping the insides out. You must cook these in the oven! Make this recipe. You will love it!

text:
For the 1000th review of this recipe, I give it 5 stars!!! My husband and I have been married for less than two years and had my in-laws over for Christmas Eve dinner in our new house.  I made two for each person and we didn't have any leftovers! In fact, I could have eaten one or two more myself. What I love about this recipe is that it seems so elegant and labor intensive, when really it's not. I did all but the last step the night before, placed them on a baking sheet and wrapped it in saran wrap in the fridge overnight. The next day when I got home from work, all I had to do was pop them in the oven to let the cheese melt.  Wondering how it would be to replace the sour cream with a little cream cheese/blue cheese mixture...

text:
I adjusted this recipe to use up leftover mashed potatoes I had in the fridge.  I added sour cream, onion powder, crisp bacon pieces and grated cheese my taters.  Placed the new mixture in a casserole dish and topped with more bacon (can't go wrong with bacon) and more grated cheese.  Cooked at 350' for 10 minutes and then broiled until browned and bubbly.  I would do this again but leave the skins on my potatoes for a baked potato casserole, a little easier than stuffing skins.

text:
Yummy!  I love these!  One thing I would recommend, especially to the people who are having trouble with the skins breaking:  make sure you are hollowing the potatoes out when they are hot.  It works much better.  I've found the best way to do this is to use a silicone kitchen mitt and hold the potatoes in one hand and scoop with a spoon with the other!  Hope this helps!

text:
Great Recipe! 

*Changes I made: 
-Instead of garlic powder, I roasted some garlic at the same time as baking the potatoes and threw a few of the roasted cloves into the mix (was awesome, I'd do this again). 
-Instead of cooking bacon I used the good pre-packaged stuff, I can't say that I missed it or noticed. 

*One thing I'll do differently next time: 
-I'll take someone's suggestion of microwaving the potatoes for 5-10 minutes to start them off. I had a hard time scooping out the potatoes that weren't as cooked, and had to microwave the mixture a couple times in order to mash them to a nice consistency.

text:
This recipe is to die for!  I added minced/pressed garlic; 1-2 cloves depending on how you like garlic, and another 1/2 cup or shredded parmesan cheese.  When I needed additional liquid I used whipping cream!  This is not an everyday recipe with Wh. Cream and sour cream, but all will love these potatoes!
I will try as suggested using the convection oven for both first and second bakes.  Labor intensive, yes, it took four of us to do enough for 24 people, but well worth every minute! 
If you love these 'killer' potatoes, try Carnie Wilson's "Fall to your knees Mac and Cheese". Another show stopper!

text:
Wonderful flavor, easy to make, and everyone loved them!  I did not change any of the ingredients or their amounts.  You can make all or part of the dish ahead of time.  If the potatoes are completely cooled when you make the filling, melt the butter in the microwave so it will blend in easily.  Then for the final baking before serving, increase the total time in the oven to 20-30 minutes, or until heated through and cheese on top is nicely melted.  I will definitely make this delicious recipe again.

These were great!  My husband and I really loved them.  I cooked the potatoes first in the microwave the night before and made them up.  I refrigerated them until I was ready to bake them in the oven.  I then baked them for about 25 minutes.  Very yummy!  I had never scooped out potatoes before so that was a little hard but well worth it.  Also I used real bacon bits instead of real bacon.  I will be making these again because it is a nice change to regular baked potatoes.

text:
I served these to company last night, and they got raves all around!  I had to double the recipe, because I just knew everyone would want more than one half (yes, we're pigs!).  I only added a touch of milk, after reading the other reviews, and that's really all it needed.  I think 1/2 cup would have been too much.  I stirred the bacon right into the potato mixture, rather than sprinkling it on top. Also, to make scraping out the potatoes easier, and to avoid breaking the skins, use a grapefruit spoon!  You can carve the outline of the amount of potato you wish to scrape, and then you can gradually scrape the potato from its skin with the grooves.  It worked like a charm!

text:
I have to say, these didn't come out exactly as intended, but it was totally my fault.  I baked them for an hour at 400 instead of 350, so the shells all but disintegrated when I went to scoop out the potato flesh.  I ended up putting everything in a casserole dish, and baking for 15 minutes.  Still turned out great!  I'll try them again for sure.  I did use fat-free sour cream, skim milk, 1 Tbl. butter, and 1/4 cup cheese to cut down on the fat - great adjustments.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Very good.  Some adjustments I would make next time...1.  Cook potatoes longer than 1 hour at 350, or bump up to 375.  2.  Use less milk - I had to cook a bit longer than indicated and filling ran and became twice baked mashed potatoes!  3.  Do not bake filled potatoes longer than indicated - see #2!
I also used bacon bits instead of real  bacon.  Excellent flavor.  Somewhat time consuming, but easy.

text:
Delicious! I made these but used hald sour cream and half cream cheese with chives and onion and probably less milk as I just poured in to suit. Don't worry about ripping the skins or not holding their shape, once you spoon a couple spoonfulls of the mixture in you can press the skins to the mixture and they stay no problem, get really close to the skin, but if you do leave some potato around the skin then season it, I didn't and you could taste when you got to the plain potato. Just a bit of ex virgin olive oil, salt and pepper would be good. I plan on making these with just the sour cream next time like the recipe says to see the difference, I also mixed hald the bacon in and sprinkled the rest on top otherwise it is too much to put on top. Many thanks

text:
These are awesome! I have also used this just as a casserole. I boil about 6 potatoes and then mash them together with the sour cream, milk, cheddar, onions, etc. Then I top with grated cheddar & bacon and bake in a 350 oven for about 30 minutes. Very yummy and less work than stuffing the potatoes (but obviously not as pretty!).

text:
Wonderful recipe!  I used 1/2 cup of chopped Walla Walla sweet onion in the mashed potato mixture instead of green onions, and topped the potatoes with 4 chopped green onions.  I also chopped the cooked, cooled bacon in the food processor and added it to the mashed potato mixture before stuffing.  This is a perfect dish to prepare the day before, then just bake when you need it.  Thank you for sharing, Debra.  This has become one of my new favorites!

mmm, these were good. Not the best I have ever had but definately the best I ever made. Served with steaks on the grill. text:
Well, this was good (because all baked potatoes are), but it did not live up to its reputation.  If I ever try this recipe again I will try broiling the potatoes after they are stuffed so that the filling will be firmer and crisper.  Save yourself the time and mush up your baked potato with your fork -- it's the same exact effect.

country:

text:
I made these for the first time for Easter this year.  I'd had twiced baked potatoes before, but not like this.  I doubled the recipe to what I thought would be enough for my whole family, but was I ever wrong!  They loved them so much they were practically fighting over who would get the last one, they went pretty quick after taking them out of the oven.  I made them again about a month later at my nephews first birthday, and once again they went fast, but this time I made enough so that there were about 3 or 4 left over.  Even my year old nephew will eat 1 or 2 to himself!  So if anyone out there is looking for something simple to make a big hit at a party, this is it!  It's great that you can take something old, and put a twist on it, just enough for people to keep coming back for more!

These potatoes are delicious. The reason I gave four stars is that I felt they would be too runny with 1/2 cup of milk and a full cup of sour cream. Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6175002.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First, microwave potatoes in microwave potato bag 4-8 minutes - very moist this way. Poke holes w/a fork lengthwise all around potatoes to makes sure they will be sliced open evenly. Wearing a pot holder glove scoop out hot potatoes carefully w/grapefruit spoon into potato ricer, then add sour cream,  finely pre-shredded Colby Jack cheese, bacon, scallions & salt to taste (no milk, add more sour cream if stiff). Bake shells lightly coated w/cooking spray 10 minutes for sturdiness. Cool shells then add potato mixture, top w/more cheese & bake in oven. Yummers! Less time, smoother & much tastier!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you need this kind of video instruction,  then you need to wait for worst cooks in America to call. If you want a bland no taste lack luster twice baked potato then you are looking at the perfect recipe. However, if you really want the best ever twice baked potato, think for yourself. What do you like? For me: To my mashed potato I add; butter, bacon (baked in the over at 350 for 12 -15 minutes or to the crispiness you like) sour cream, cheese, heavy whipping cream, seasoned salt, minced garlic, chopped green onions, and fresh ground black pepper to taste. I save some bacon, green onion and cheese to put on top half way through the second bake. When they come out of the oven, sprinkle with smoked paprika and fresh cilantro. Tell me this is not the "Ultimate Twice Baked Potato." You're welcome!

text:
These are awesome! I used the same recipe with only two large potatoes and they still came out tasting amazing. I've never made a twice baked potato so be careful with scooping the flesh out. It's easiest if you cut it out like an avocado. Use criss-cot cuts on the flesh, then carefully use a spoon. Don't just dig with a spoon like it's a tub of ice cream.

text:
I make these a couple times a year. When I make them I make a large quantity (25 or so) and then I freeze them. They freeze very well and just take them out as you want them for a meal. Make sure you taste the potato mash & add more salt/pepper to your taste. You can also baste the potato skins in melted butter & put them in the oven on broil to crisp the skin up and then fill the potato with the mash after.

text:
First off, very good flavor.  A little "runnier" than I prefer; although I only used about 1/4 cup milk, perhaps next time I'll cut down on the sour cream by 1/2 cup or perhaps add an egg or cream cheese. I tried one reviewer's idea to only cut the top 1/3 of the baked potato off, making more of a bowl shaped shell, which looked really nice, but then I found I had too much filling for half the amount of shells (instead of 8 halves to fill I only had 4 slightly deeper ones). That was okay, though, I just nuked the leftover filling in a bowl and ate it with a spoon! Yum! Cook's treat!

userID:
1218893
Display Name:
Colleen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
13
favoritesCount:
86
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Here is my variation which is an assortment of suggestions found in other reviews and they turned out awesome.  I cooked the bacon ahead of time and used the drippings to coat the potato with before baking.  I only cut the top 1/3 of the potato off.  I used 1/2 c sour cream and 1/2 cup herb and garlic cream cheese.  For the cheese, I used herb and garlic cheddar.  Substituted chives for the onions.  I only added enough milk to get the consistency I wanted.  I added everything in (saved nothing for toppings).  I used the top 1/3 skin that was cut off and placed it in the bottom of the scooped out shell (gives it extra texture in the bottom and there is no waste).  I used the nipped zip lock bag method for filling the potato.  Made them early in the day, kept them in the fridge and when ready for the second bake , I cooked them for 40 minutes at 350 (they were large russets).

text:
Reading the recipe I thought 1 cup of sour cream for 4 large potatoes seemed like an awful lot and after adding it realized I should have followed that impression.  I like the ingredients and the potential for flavor but next time I will use less sour cream and see how it turns out.  It was too much even for the 5 large potatoes I made.  From trial and error I found that using a knife to cut around the edge of the potato halves made removing the flesh and keeping the skin in tact much easier.

text:
I made mine with the red skin potatoes.  I wrapped them in foil with some butter and baked at 350 for an hour.  I cut 1/3 off, scraped potato from lid and remainder of potato, being careful not to scrape too close to the skin.  Before I refilled the potatoes, I placed the lid skin in the bottom.  I added a little sour cream while mashing.  Filled, then topped with remaining bacon and cheese.  Baked 20 minutes at 350, then topped with chives.  SCRUMPTIOUS :))))

text:
Incredible - a lot of work but worth it.  I haven't tried freezing yet but that would make it even better since it's a long process.  I agree with another reviewer that they are a little soupy so I should have eased up on milk.  I did follow another's advice and squished them a little bit to make them fluffy.  I don't really know if that made a difference but I did it.  I subbed cream cheese for half of sour cream and that was tasty - I usually add both to my mashed potatoes.  I tripled the recipe since I had a lot of guests coming. If you do double or triple, don't cut all of the potatoes and then scoop...the potatoes started cooling too much which made scooping more difficult.  Cutting 4 at a time would have been better.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I really like this recipe,It is easy and can be quick using potatoes that are already baked. I made a few changes to the prep which knocked off an hour of cooking time. I followed  all PONYGIRS64'S ingredients exactly as written. However, I made some short cuts for which I will use in the future. I had potatoes that were leftover from a previous night's dinner. I removed the flesh from the spuds into a microwavable bowl. Then I added the milk, butter, sour cream,cheese,and the salt and pepper. I nuked all of those ingredients until the butter and cheese were melted,and tosed in the green onons...  I proceeded with the recipe exactly as written. While the potatoes were baking I zapped the bacon in my microwave for 5 minutes. (since microwaves differ adjust to your microwave)...I had time to crumble the now cooled bacon to garnish along with the cheese and green onion. I will make this recipe on a regular basis, keeping in mind to bake extra potatoes ahead of time. My family loved them. This recipe is a definite keeper.

userID:
13777212
Display Name:
yyzfoodscene
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/17.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight as a main dish with a side salad. I didn't follow the recipe exactly , I omitted the sour cream and bacon completely didn't feel it was necessary for my personal taste and waistline :). I made my mixture with salted butter and roasted up 2 cloves of garlic added broccoli florets, green onion finely chopped, paprika and a dash of salt and i added the milk (warmed) a teaspoon at a time until i reached the desired consistency. I topped with shredded cheddar and put back in the oven until the cheese melted then quickly turned on the broiler to get it just a bit crispy. It was amazing so full of flavour and that was mainly because of the roasted garlic which was not over powering.

 I also seasoned my shells before baking with an olive oil rub and some course salt. The only thing that I might change next time is halfway through the baking process is to remove the potatoes from the foil and let the skins get a bit crispier, other then that i would make it the same way with an addition of black olives on top. These were delightful and will be added to my dinner rotation, my 6 yr old loved it.

text:
Extremely delicious, my whole family wanted more than one! One thing however, one hour at 350 was definitely not enough to cook such large potatoes. I put them in the microwave for ten minutes and then in the oven for an hour and they were perfect! Also, make sure not to dig too deep taking the potatoe out of the skin because the skin will break and it will not work!

text:
It is really hot so I didn't want to turn on the oven for that long.  I first cooked them in the microwave for about 15 minutes.  I than scooped them out leaving out the milk and butter and put them in the oven just until the cheese on top was melted.  This saved a lot of time and prevented my from dying in my kitchen from the heat.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/520478.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I do it the lazy way! I cut off the top 1 inch of a large, well washed Russet potato, stick it into a coffee cup cut side up, cover it with cellophane film and nuke it for 12 minutes. The moisture from the washing helps the spud to cook thoroughly and scooping out the flesh is a cinch using a teaspoon, just let it cool about 4 minutes. Do your thing with the flesh like above and you have the perfect twice baked potato. I just add whatever I feel like adding at the time and never had any complaints. Oh! btw, I do this at my Restaurant also! LOL! You'd be surprised how many great comments I get!

text:
Beyond Scrumptious! Used reviewers suggestions for milk: used 1/4 cup. Added 1/2 tsp garlic powder. Slightly mashed taters first to avoid overmixing for lumps. Important to find thick-skinned taters - had a bit of a mess due to too thin skins, but just as delicious. Next time will add fresh baby spinach or diced green or red pepper to mixture before second bake. Served with grilled asparagus with diced mushrooms. Success and sooooo yummy.

country:
None
text:
These are the best double baked potatoes I've ever had!! Like most people do, I did tweak it for our tastes.  I excluded the onion and added a clove of garlic instead.  I also used marble cheese instead of a sharp cheddar just because that's what we had on hand, I'm sure cheddar would have been even more amazing. One other thing I did that wasn't mentioned in the recipe, I rubbed the potatoes with olive oil and lightly salted them before baking, this made the skin tasty and just a bit crispy. These potatoes will definitely end up on our dinner table again soon!

text:
Perfect just as is!  Well I snuck in a tad (2 tbls) more butter but that was a personal preference.  If you use 4 large baking potatoes as stated you will need to bake them a little longer. Not too runny at all so my potatoes must have been just right!  I made the day before and baked for some friends. When one of them asked for butter I asked him to try them first.  He did and passed on the butter as they were so creamy and delicious!  I am always looking for a "cook ahead" recipe for when we entertain and this will be on the top of the list!  We froze a couple up as someone suggested! YUMMY

None
text:
I used 6 medium potatoes, which I baked in the microwave for about 14 minutes. I increased the salt to 1 tsp. They came out great; very creamy and delicious. The only thing I would do differently is to reduce the amount of sour cream to 3/4 cup and use more than half of the cheese and onion in the filling and less on top, because there was so much, it was hard to get it to stay on the potatoes. Great recipe!

userID:
7198548
Display Name:
Scott Duerk
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7765563.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WE LOVE THIS recipe!  Made it the other night for me and my wife.  Very easy to make and I took adivce from a couple of other  reviews and eased up on the sour cream.  I also used Russet potatoes that are wrapped in a cooking "bag" for microwave use.  Since I used 2 large potatoes, I "nuked" them together for 10 minutes and to my surprise, they came out perfect.  Instead of using a hand mixer to make a creamy mixture, I used a fork to grind up and mix everything together.  The filling did have lumps, but that was fine for us both.  Using the fork also helped keep the filling from getting to "creamy".  Overall, this was delicous, easy to make and definitely a keeper.

text:
Mmmmmmmmmmmmmm....so good!!! To make these ULTIMATE twice baked potataoes so lunch, I did make a few changes. First, when I baked the potatoes, I rubbed each in olive oil and salt then wrapped them in aluminum foil. Next, I replaced the sour cream with cream cheese, the chedder cheese with pepper jack, and the green onions with red. I also didn't use any bacon. They came out AMAZING! Will definitley make them again and again and again! :)

text:
These were delicious! I made them for my mom's birthday and she absolutely loved them. I never thought of using a hand mixer to mix the filling before. It made it so smooth and creamy.
I decided to put the filling into a Ziploc bag and fill the potatoes and then smooth it with the back of a teaspoon. This made it easy to fill and know when they were evenly distributed.
I managed to break a few of the skins, but luckily they are really easy to mold once you have the stuffing in.

text:
I have made these potatoes for many years - I like them better without bacon (a personal choice) and I mix all the ingredients together before stuffing the potato skins. Then I sprinkle a layer of Parmesan of or Romano cheese over the top.  I bake them a little longer until the Parmesan/Romano cheese starts to brown.  Everybody likes these potatoes - even the picky eaters.

userID:
5198321
Display Name:
a.stokes
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
49
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My stepmom and I have made this for years. We dont save the skins and it is much simpler and quicker. Bake the potatoes through out. Spoon out the inside into a large bowl, down to the skin. Discard skin. Add sour cream, butter, salt and pepper (all to your taste prefrence). Mash with fork, it will get stuck and not mix well with the hand mixer. Then add bacon bits or frispy bacon pieces, cheese and diced green onions. Mix well. Sprinkle cheese and bacon bits on top. Put in microwave about five minutes to reheat and melt cheese. It is just as good and folks can get a larger serving than when you put it back in the skin. Everybody that has it loves it.  You can also substitue the butter and sour cream with either miracle whip or ranch dressing. The flavor is a little different but just as delicious.

We are eating less meat, so I omitted the bacon, and just estimated the other ingredients, since my potatoes were kind of small. A splash of milk, a dollop of cream, etc...til I had a nice creamy but still chunky mixture. Anyway, they were delicious, and even the hubby liked them and he is a potato purist. text:
These potatoes are absolutely delicious! The recipe is perfect as is, and you don't need to change a thing. Those who are tearing the skins are probably trying to scoop too much of the flesh out of the insides.  It's perfectly ok (and practical) to leave some of the potato inside (1/4 in. around the sides and bottom) to preserve the skins.

text:
Very good. I tried these because I am looking for recipes I can do ahead for Thanksgiving dinner and Kristy's review said they freeze well.  I have one in the freezer and if it gets a passing grade from hubby and I they will be on that table Thanksgiving Day.  I will definitely make these again.  I reduced the milk to 1/4 cup because after making them a few times I found that they sometimes came out a bit runny, probably due to the potato's I used but that solved the problem.  Always make more than I need and put the extras in the freezer and just heat them up when I need them.
