text:
Best loaded potatoes ever.  As other reviews have said if the potato is completely cool you'll have a much easier time scooping out the flesh.  One time I was lazy and instead of scooping out the flesh, putting it back in the potato, etc. I just turned it into loaded mashed potatoes, excellent that way as well.  This is a great dish to make the day before and then refrigerate after you put the loaded mixture back in the shells and pop back in the oven the next day for reheating.

definitely better when made with mini red-skinned potatoes!  I just sliced them in half prior to baking, spraying the cooking sheet with an olive oil spray and then spraying the potato skins once placed cut-side down on the table.  I baked them for about 20 minutes at 425 degrees.  Important note:  keep in mind it will take a lot more of these, and be careful when mixing the insides of the potatoes; it can turn to soup faster than you'd imagine!

country:

text:
A tasty recipe - served with grilled steak and Maple Dill Carrots, also from this site. I made a few changes - I used 1/2 cup of light sour cream and 4 ounces of light cream cheese (which I had on hand - so a good way to use it up) for the 1 cup of sour cream. When mixing the potato mixture, I added half of the  bacon to the ingredients, saving the rest for the top as directed. I made the potatoes ahead of time, refrigerated them, and baked for 40 minutes in a 350 degree oven before serving. I had some spillage over the sides of the potato cases - but I attribute that to the 'light' products - not the recipe. The potatoes were delicious.

text:
I have made these twice in the past week. Once as my family's potato choice for Christmas day and another time for a staff Christmas party. Both times I made them the day before and then popped them in the oven 30 min. before we ate. They were perfect. Nice and creamy!  I will note that I did add about 3 oz of cream to each batch just like I do when making GOOD mashed potatoes.  Put the mix in a zip lock bag and snip off the corner to fill your potato halves. If you want to make it super fancy, use a 1M piping tip.
Try this one you will love it!

country:

text:
Cooking for one...I used one microwave ready Russet potato (in plastic).  It said to microwave for 7-8 minutes so I choose 7 minutes and let it sit for 10 minutes as instructed.  I cut the potato in half and the skin fell off so I had to adapt the recipe.  I put the potato in a ramkin and mashed the ingredients together.  It was chunky, not creamy and I baked it as directed.  The taste was fabulous but it was a little dry (not bad though) so next time I would probably add another tablespoon of milk.  The flavors really melt together and you don't need any salt.  Will make again!

I would not recommend this recipe. 1 full cup of sour cream is far too much. When added to a 1/2 cup of milk you're left with a soupy consistency that wrecks 1.25 hours of preparation. Most recipes call for half the amount of sour cream (or no milk), so stick with one of those.

They are perfect and saved me some time.

text:
I've made this recipe at least 10 times. Whenever I feel like having potatoes I use this recipe- it's so much tastier than a basic potato, and you don't have to worry about the kids getting the fixin's all over! I've used lots of different cheeses and I separate it into 2 batches, adding the onion to the "adult" batch and I add more bacon to the kid batch to make it more appealing to my 2 & 4 year old boys. This is my standby dinner! Update: I recently made these with an added 1/2 cup pureed cauliflower and a 1/2 cup of cooked, pureed navy beans. It was FANTASTIC. Not only did the potatoes have more nutrition, but the taste was more full AND it made it so each potato skin had more stuffing! I will only do this from now on!!

text:
Well, these were....okay.  The consistency wasn't as creamy and smooth as I had hoped for.  My husband can't eat them b/c he is low-carbing it right now.  I had one for dinner and will have one for lunch today.  I froze the other two for a quick lunch or snack later on.  They seem to freeze well.  I followed the recipe with only one change and that was I used less green onions than called for...about half.  I think next time I will add a couple tablespoons of cream cheese to the mix and see if that gives it the consistency that I want.  UPDATE: 9/16/2006; I tried again and added 2 Tbsp of reduced fat cream cheese and this made it much, much better.

text:
The recipe does not include any instructions on how to bake the potatoes. Having never made twice baked potatoes before, I wrapped mine in tinfoil the first time with disasterous results - the skins were unusable and I had to spoon the mixture into a muffin tray. That said, the taste was nice, and second time around, with advice from others, I coated potatoes in oil and salt and didn't wrap them in anything, and it turned out wonderfully! Also, I'm a vegetarian, so omitted the bacon, but may try with BacoBits or veggie bacon.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/49.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe takes some time, but it's well-worth the effort. I get requests for them whenever we have people over for dinner. For me, the trick is to MAKE SURE your potatoes are fully cooked before making the filling. Then I just add the liquid (milk, sour cream, etc) as needed--sometimes I need more and sometimes less. After one or two tries you definitely get the hang of it.

Rating:

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried these last night doing only two large bakers (russets). A little time consuming but a very good loaded twice baked potato recipe. If you want the skins to be a little more "crisp" so they're easier to work with, scrub taters well, pat dry and rub a small amount of tub margarine all over the skin and put directly on the oven rack. You will still need to use a knife (or spoon) to outline where you are scooping. I baked these about 1 hr and 15 min. as these were good sized potatoes. My 20 yr old son actually asked me did I really make those or did I buy them. I will make again for a family function/holiday.

text:
Yummy!!  I added about 1/4 cup more sour cream to make them tangier, used 1 1/2 c cheddar in the mixture and 1/2 cup on top, and added a bit more milk to make them creamier.  I also buttered and salted (w/coarse salt) the potato skins before serving.  My grandma always makes these without the bacon, and as a result I'm not sure it's necessary, but it certainly wasn't a horrible addition.  Am happy to have found this recipe!  Plan on bringing to a get together in a few weeks!  Thanks :)

text:
These were sooo good.  There were no leftovers - next time I will make more.
A few changes - I used half the sour cream and cheese because I ran out.  Used only 2 T. Butter to cut fat.  I didn't have any chives, so instead, I added French's Onions to the top about five minutes before they were done baking.  I also baked in a 9x9 pan - less work.  This recipe is impossible to screw up!  I will be making for all my parties from now on.

text:
This recipe was wonderful.  I substituted colby jack cheese for the cheddar because it's what I had, but that didn't hurt the taste or texture.  The one thing I noticed was that at 350, those large baking potatoes won't get done in an hour.  I baked mine at 450 and it still took an hour and twenty minutes.  Next time I'll use smaller potatoes.  But the recipe itself is solid and the flavor of the onion with the sour cream was great.  I also added garlic powder and parsely, and would have thrown in chives if they were in season.  Every bite disappeared.

Very tasty potatoes.  I didn't put the green onions in because I forgot to buy them.  I think the flavor would have been better with them or some onion.  I suggest adding the milk slowly as you beat them so you can control the consistency.  I followed the recipe and I thought they were a little too wet.  I used a melon baller to scrap the potato out.  I was able to get right down to the potato skin without breaking it.  I will make them again with a few other variations.  Overall very good.

text:
What a great recipe!  I love the way you can alter the recipe to suit whatever you have in the pantry or what you're in the mood for.  I only had Idaho russet potatoes, but they worked fine.  I used low-fat ingredients and left out the green onions and bacon since I didn't have any around.  Instead I added minced garlic and dried chives.  Wow!  My husband has never had any twice-baked potatoes other than the packaged, frozen kind, so he was doubtful he'd like these.  Instead he found himself scarfing them down and telling me I should make them again! I plan to, but want to play around with the ingredients, adding things like turkey bacon, chopped broccoli, and so on.  These are practically a meal in themselves, especially with a nice green salad for a side.

text:
Made these yesterday, refrigerated overnight, brought back to room temp this morning and heated at 350 for 30 minutes.  What I learned is that the potatoes must be gently mashed together with the other ingredients, and a bit stiff when you spoon it back into the shell.  The cheese and such in the mix adds wetness.  Watch how much milk you add.  My next batch will be perfect.  The flavor is awesome, and I followed this recipe exactly.  Thanks.

text:
We have this at least once a week and this is our main course!  I completely omit the milk, butter and green onion.  After scooping the potatoes, I add salt, pepper, thick sliced bacon, x-sharp shredded cheddar, hand mash, then top with more bacon and cheese!  So fattening but so good!  My hubby likes me to cook these for about 20-25 minutes so that the potatoes "pancake" (or spread) on the cookie sheet.  One of my hubby's fave's!  Thanks Debra!

This was great! I added 2 cups of broccoli (cut the florets small) to 2/3 cup of water and 1/4 tsp of salt. Covered and boiled for 3-5 mins (until just tender) and then drained. I prepared the potato mixture as the recipe indicated and after I had combined ingredients using the hand mixer, I then folded in the broccoli. Turned out great!

This was incredible. Used 4 large BAKING potatoes as stated and subbed the green onion for chives and bacon bits for bacon. Took almost 3 hours to be done where they took so long to cook.

text:
If you’re just making a small amount, I suggest not cutting the potatoes in half. If you cut the top off (just enough to scoop out the inners) they look a whole lot better. Oh and placing them in a baking dish as you put the topping on for the second round of cooking. Works really great and you don’t waste any toppings.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I rate it a 10 ! They are fabulous ! 
When i heat my oven for something, I usually make it count. I’ll bake at least 10 large potatoes so this makes at least 20 meals, after doubling if course.  You can have them ready for unexpected company, long hard days or a helping hand to someone who’s caring for an aging parent.  Whatever the case,.... they’re in your freezer. 
I dont put the ones I'm freezing, back in the oven the second time. I cool them and put them in the freezer so when I vacuum seal, I’m not crushing them. Yep. Just on a sheet pan uncovered is fine. Just don’t forget about them.  Then when completely frozen, put into a vacuum seal bag, pull all the air and seal.  
Thanks for this spectacular side !

userID:
25677797
Display Name:
dukedc
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
4

8
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this and my family thought it was the best they have tasted. I used MEDIUM SIZED Russet potatoes, did some minor changes as well. I coated the potatoes in olive oil and sprinkled them with Kosher Salt completely. I also used chives rather than Green Onions and baked the potatoes at 400 degrees rather than 350 for 1 hour.  I found this to get my skins crispier.  DO NOT scrape them all the way to the skin, you need to leave them about 1/8 - 1/4 inch thick around the inside.


NOTE: you need to use Russet or Idaho potatoes as well. These are high in starch,thicker skinned 
and what makes for the best BAKED POTATOES. I saw some complaints about them being to soft and mushy and I bet they were using something other than a high starch potato. Also cooking times need to be adjusted for the size of the potato.

5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are great!  I always bake up a whole bag of potatoes at one time.  Prepare as twice baked and freeze them.  It is so nice to be able to remove how ever many  are needed, thaw in the frig. and serve with a ham steak or whatever .  Thanks for the great recipe.
Update:  Last time I baked 10 lbs of potatoes, once potatoes were baked I dug out most of the potatoe and left the skins with a thin layer of potatoe.  Froze the mashed potatoes seperate from the skins.  Now I can have; twice baked, mashed or potatoe skins.  This worked great! Last night we had potatoe skins stuffed with a chicken mixture and lots of cheese on top.  One more variation for the menu from the freezer.  Thank you so much for sharing the idea of freezing twice baked potatoes.

I made these last night, they turned out fantastic. I did run into a problem with the potatoes, The 350 degrees didn't seem to be cooking them for the hour. So, I put a couple more in for an hour at 400 and those turned out fantastic.

text:
I followed the recipe as written and my family loved it. My daughter kept asking me to make again and again. Now, I add different cheeses like smoked Gouda and havarti. I also add some fresh herbs to the mixture; thyme, rosemary and sage. I chop them up fine. Since we love garlic, I now include 1 crushed garlic clove. After baking the potatoes I do score the inside and gently scrape the flesh with a serrated spoon. The smell of them baking is mouth-watering!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe.  I generally followed this recipe.  Making it again tonight.  The only changes I would make include.  

No need to puncture potatoes before baking.  I have never done this and don't believe there is a genuine need.

The majority of ingredients are included in the mixture, especially the bacon, onion and cheese.  I leave out only a minimal amount for the sake of garnish (appearance). 

I don't tear the bacon by hand, preferring a butcher knive to chop it up into smaller pieces.

That's about it.  Again, wonderful recipe.  Easy but takes a little time.

Rating:
3

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ive made this a handful of times. Learned a few things on the way. Read other reviews!! I wrap my potatoes in foil and place in toaster over at 400 after about 1 1/2 hours when they feel soft they are done. Trust me, you want them soft. You also want to use large potatoes. When scraping out potato leave a bit on the edges and bottom so they won’t “break”. I cook a whole package of bacon then crumble all of it up. No one complains about too much bacon. You can even leave these in fridge. Easy to throw them in the microwave for a quick snack. Oh and I just put a bunch of cheese, no need to measure.  This is NOT a low fat side! Thanks for the recipe. They don’t last long in our house.

text:
Love this recipe. Family asks for it every holiday dinner. We add garlic for a bit more flavor. Someone suggested easing up on the milk. I disagree otherwise the potato is so dense. Light and fluffy with richness is what you get if you follow the recipe. Reheats well in the oven too Incase you have leftovers. I try to make extra, but never end up with any. It’s that yummy. Best twice baked potato recipe I’ve tried thus far. No need to lol further.

0
madeRecipesCount:
15
favoritesCount:
109
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4693797.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
To make this vegan, omit bacon and use substitutes for sour cream, butter, milk, and cheese. There are vegan bacon recipes out there if you want to go the extra mile. The brands we use for substitutes: Tofutti vegan sour cream, Earth Balance butter, Silk almond milk, and Daiya cheddar cheese. I added onion powder and used the mixer to blend the ingredients for the filling. Daiya vegan cheese tastes good, but doesn’t blend or melt easily. Having the cheese broken up and distributed by the blender helps with consistency and melting. Instead of topping with more cheese, I topped with paprika and dill. It was a hit! None of this one to put away after Thanksgiving. It was all gone!

userID:

Display Name:
Cari Baker

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always try to make things as streamlined as possible, as the mother of 4 with a more than full time regular  job.  While the potatoes baked (I wet them and coated them lightly in sea salt for a crispier skin), I put the filling ingredients in a gallon ziplock bag (including all the bacon, which I bought precooked and chopped)and left it on counter to soften butter.  After cooling baked potatoes I used a melon ball scoop to extract the potato interior.  I added that to the ziplock bag and mixed the ingredients by hand (I love kneading bread,etc), by just massaging the contents of the bag and breaking up potato chunks.  As another person suggested, I cut the corner of the ziplock off and piped the filling in and continued with the recipe instructions.  Throw away the ziploc bag & no bowl or mixer parts to clean.  And if you put foil down on baking sheet you don't have to clean it and can also use it to keep potatoes hot if you aren't ready when they are!
Review:
Rating:
5

Basically a good basic recipe Only comment I have is to NOT wrap the potatoes in foil to bake. The skin will hold up better to complete the process of making this recipe. The foil on the potatoes makes the skin softer and less easy to work with.

Display Name:
artbysarah

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/327881.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Using smaller russets? Rub a light coat of olive oil on each potato, sprinkle with kosher salt, and wrap in foil. Place directly on the oven rack. After you've baked them, remove from foil and place on cooling rack. After they have cooled off 10-15 minutes, the skin will crisp up a little so they won't tear when you scoop the flesh out.  I used a melon baller which worked PERFECTLY for smaller potatoes. Oh, and I also added half of the crumbled bacon into the mixture.  YUM!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made these tonight and they were delicious! I added a packet of lipton dry vegetable soup, and did 1/2 sour cream and 1/2 cream cheese, shredded cheese and crumbled bacon (left over from this mornings breakfast) I cut some fresh chives from my herb garden, and snipped them up into tiny pieces added to the mix. Leaving some of the potato in the skin and remaking for 15 minutes made it perfect. Thank you to the reviewer who recommended using a meatball scooper, it made getting the potato out easy and saved the skins.  Scooped the mix back into the potato boats, topped with shredded cheese, crumbled bacon and snipped chives.
My son took his 1st bite and said "WOW!" with my husband following suit. This is now on my favorites list!

text:
This a great recipe for twice baked potatoes! I turned my oven to 350 as suggested and cooked for an hour, and when time was up, the potato was just a wee bit hard when I cut it so I tossed it in the microwave for a few minutes. Cooking time will vary depending on your oven and the size of potato. Oh, I didn't cut the potato in half-I just cut the top off which makes a really good shell for the pulp mixture. I just eyeballed the milk, sour cream and butter.  I totally love cheese so I just went to town on it! I would definitely make this again and again. Thank you so much for this!!

text:
I made this yesterday for our Christmas Eve dinner, and it  was a huge hit!  I used about two tablespoons of dried chives instead of the onions.   I also used Russet potatoes instead of baking potatoes, and I wouldn't recommend doing that.  After an hour of baking, the potatoes still were hard and I had to microwave them for a little.  Next time, I'll listen to the recipe and use baking potatoes!

Rating:
5

None
text:
You can make this dish a day or two ahead of time. Do not bake it. After topping with bacon and cheese, just cover with plastic wrap and put in the refrigerator.  take it out of the refrigerator and let it sit out at room temperature for about one hour or a little longer. This will cut down on baking time. Bake about 1.25 hours but watch them.  Spoon the mixture into plastic bag, snip corner of bag and squeeze  to fill potato skins.

city:

country:
None
text:
I've made these for holidays for at least 3 years now.  A couple changes and tips might help:
Bake the potatoes at 425 for an hour and 10 min
Put the potatoes in the fridge to cool while I prepare the other ingredients.
Mix everything into the potatoes.
Use a knife to loosen the flesh 1/4-1/8 inch from the skin so it won't tear.
Put potato mixture in a Ziploc and pipe it into the skins.

Hope this helps!

text:
The secret to firm skins which withstand the scooping process is to NOT wrap them in foil; oil + salt and bake is all they need. Foil will keep the skins moist and soft, which is undesirable.

country:
None
text:
I have made these several times now without changing a thing on the recipe, and they are just too good.  Make sure to not scoop out to much flesh near the skin of the potato, which you're going to want to do, but don't do it.  A thick layer at the bottom keeps the potato intact, and there is so much flavor going on top you won't be left with a bland potato.  Trust me.  These are quite filling though, so don't plan for too many sides.
Review:

Display Name:
Yvette Yvonne

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making these for over 20 years and usually a few times a month as my family loves them. For my potatoes I only buy the huge russett potatoes and after I wash them I baste them with a little bit of olive oil and season them with bucks seasoning or whatever I'm in the mood for. My children who never ate the skin now ask for everyone elses skin. When It is time to scoop out the potato I cut a diamond shape in the top of the potatoes about 3 inches long by 2 inches wide. It gives you plenty of room to scoop them and when you fill them I always top it coming out of the potatoes so you don't even see it. I have also try some different add-ins. I use tiny broccoli florets,  I've used tiny bits of mushrooms, cream cheese and I have a potato topper that I mix in as well as sprinkle on top of the cheese and Bacon. My kids absolutely love these and I always make about 15 so I can vacuum pack them and freeze them. I am cooking these now so I will post a pic of what I mean when they are finished.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
love twice baked potatoes. We owned a steak house & made twice baked all of the time. Just a hint about baking the potatoes. Scrub them well, dry, then rub with small amount of vegetable shortening. Place on baking sheet & bake 1 hour. Allow to cool enough to cut in two lengthwise & scoop out flesh. Add butter, sour cream & ranch dressing. Mix well & stuff back in to skins. Top with favorite toppings & bake until cheese is melty & slightly browned. Baking the potatoes in this way makes the skins nice & firm & crispy.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were excellent! I made a few changes. I'm the only one in my family who likes bacon, so I just topped mine before the 2nd bake with Hormel real bacon bits. Everything else went into the mix. We added shredded cheese on top for the 2nd bake. I don't like my potatoes mushy, so I skipped the milk. We think potatoes need garlic, so I used garlic butter I made with fresh minced garlic from my garden. (If you like garlic but don't want it really strong, roast some while potatoes bake.) And I just used a fork to mix it all up; no need for a hand mixer (which would probably only work with the milk in it anyway).

Good recipe. I've made twice baked potatoes before so I already knew that you need to use a large russets and bake them very thoroughly. Then you've got to let them cool pretty well so that they can be handled easily during the scooping. For my taste they needed more salt, and I would have buttered the skins and wrapped the potatoes in foil for baking.

text:
Great recipe. I rub my potatoes with olive oil, stab with a fork here and there (so steam is released and potato skins are crisp), sprinkle with sea or kosher salt and bake at 400 degrees for 45 min + depending on size of potatoes.  I cut 1/3rd off lengthwise and use the large 2/3rd to stuff and the 1/3rd for appetizers.

country:
None
text:
Made the recipe last night, almost exactly, just left out butter and milk and only mashed the centers with sour cream alone. It was moist enough. This recipe is fantastic. It might seem like one of those "you can do it without the recipe" kinds of things but I NEVER would have guessed to mash them with sour cream and re-bake. Everyone saw them on their plate when served and eyes lit up like it was Christmas!!! My daughter ate one half and said "too bad you don't make these all the time" ... well, I can make them a lot more often now that I know how!!!! Sometimes the simplest things are the best, this is one of those times! Instead of wrapping potatoes in foil and baking I lightly greased them with vegetable oil (a trick my grandma taught me) Thanks for a fantastic recipe, and I don't think me omitting milk or butter is enough ground to re-write and publish a recipe, claiming it as my own, I am sure mine tasted exactly how they should have :)

text:
I'm asked to make this almost weekly, everyone devours these! I've used large potatoes and smaller russet potatoes, the larger ones are better but if you only have small one on hands, go ahead and use em (except add 2 extra ones to get enough filling). I add 4oz cream cheese, extra cheddar (I never measure it out I just dump some in) and use bacon bits to save time. You will not be disappointed!

text:
I halved the recipe (so 2 potatoes). On 350, the potatoes took about 80 minutes, but could probably have come out at 75 (tried at 60 and they weren't quite ready), as one burst a little bit. My mixture needed the milk (I saw others were saying it made it soupy, but I didn't experience that), but maybe it's because I mixed mine by hand, not with a mixer (didn't want them too starchy). They were good and all, but a lot of time and work for what wasn't a whole lot better than most other potato recipes. I'd try a different twice-baked recipe next time - something with spices or vegetables or something more flavorful than just what amounts to a loaded baked potato. oh, and there were too many green onions.

text:
Absolutely delicious! I was making a large quantity for a family dinner so I mixed all the cheese and bacon into the mashed potato mix. I served the green onions on the side. I used white pepper instead of black pepper. I also used plain yogurt in place of sour cream and chicken stock in place of milk to lighten them up just a bit. I added the stock last gradually so I could get the perfect consistency. Our family loved them, even picky young ones who don't eat mashed potatoes. This recipe is a keeper!

text:
Made these for over 20 years. We like to OVER STUFF the potatoes.. I simply bake extra potatoes to add to the mixture and discard the skins of the extra ones. This way you can  leave more potato on the skins and the skins will stay firm..............Being from Louisiana where we love crayfish, I sometimes plate the potato in a bowl and ladle with crawfish ettoufee and it becomes an entree instead of a side dish. Shrimp or crabmeat can be substituted.

These were amazing! The only issue I had was preventing the potato skins from falling apart (being too tender). It works great for a nice soft baked potato, but maybe my technique needs to change in order to provide a skin that will hold up better?

text:
These potatoes were delicious.  I didn't have bacon so I had to skip that part, and I only put in about half a cup of light sour cream and maybe 1 1/2 tbsps of butter just to cut down on the calories and they still turned out amazing...my husband ate three of them in one sitting!  If you want to save time baking the potatoes, throw them in the microwave on high for ten minutes instead of in the oven for an hour.  Then make them as per the recipe and finish them off in the oven.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2992892.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make these also with the following changes.  I will chop up an onion & mix in with the mashed potatoes.  Instead of mixing in shredded cheese, I slice pieces of cheese about 1/4" x 1/4" and about 1/2 -3/4" long.  Once I have restuffed the potato halves, I poke the cheese sticks down into the potato halves (maybe 8-10 sticks per half depending on their size).  This gives you little pockets of cheese when you are eating them.  I then sprinkle paparika on them and brown them in the oven until the cheese melts.  I also use the "real bacon bits" you get in the salad section.

text:
I served these twice-baked potatoes alongside the baby back ribs recipe from this website.  My husband was in love.  Instead of baking the potatoes in the oven (I had to use the oven to slow-cook the ribs), I cooked them in the microwave; it didn't compromise the taste at all, and it was much quicker.  When I was done using the oven for the ribs, I put the potatoes in to melt the cheese and heat through.  I think we could've made a meal out of this, and we would have if we didn't have the ribs to eat, too!

userID:
4958496
Display Name:
lakelady

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These potatoes are fantastic and the leftovers are just as good, if not better, than fresh out of the oven...at least the way I made them.  I followed this recipe for our dinner and made a few extra potato "boats". I think I might have used a little more grated cheese on the tops when I baked them because they were really covered nicely with cheese.  You'll see why that's important next. The next night I added a little margarine to a non stick skillet and heated it on medium high heat.  I placed the cold potato boats, skin side down, in the pan and and cooked until I knew the bottom of the skins were browned...about 5 mins.  I didn't distrub them after I placed them in the pan.  I wanted a nice unbroken crisp bottom. Next I added another tablespoon of margarine to the skillet and carefully slide a spatula under each potato and quickly turned it over, cheese side down. I placed the spatula squarely on top of each potato skin and pressed down to flatten them to about half it's original thickness.  Now just let it brown in the margarine for another 5 mins on medium heat without disturbing.  The cheese will get nice and brown and crispy.  Remove the potato to the dinner plate but let it sit a few mins before eating.  These left over potatoes tasted so much like cheesy potato onion perogies. I made this recipe again tonight and this time made 4 extra potatoes for leftovers. This is a keeper!!

text:
These were good! I didn't have a problem with the skin staying intact because I followed the advice of other reviewers. I picked large baking potatoes. When I split them in half, I used the knife to slice about 1/4 in inside the skin and scooped out the flesh with a spoon. It was very easy with the knife. The only thing I did differently was to use extra bacon (pre-cooked) and about 2/3 of the green onion. I also added some of the bacon and paprika to the filling. Next time, I think I'll add even more bacon and still less onion (or use chives instead).

UPDATE: I made these again for New Year's and followed the suggestions I had last time about using more bacon and chives instead of the onion. They were great! Everyone loved them. I even made a vegan version for some vegetarian/lactose intolerant friends with vegan sour cream and veggie cheese, and they told me those were great, as well.

I felt that for the true baking potatoes I had, the original cooking time was definitely too short...I'll be trying again shortly with extra time added to the cooking stages.  I can only imagine the baking potatoes I had were much larger than the ones this recipe was designed for, so make sure to leave a little extra time in case you need to cook your potatoes longer.  Remember, you can always place these in the fridge or tightly wrapped in the freezer if you end up making them early and the rest of dinner isn't ready!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Perfect rendition of a beloved childhood comfort food. I made these exactly as printed, except I used soy milk as that's all I ever buy. I've made them twice in two weeks--a record for me. We served them with ribs for company the first time and rotisserie chicken the second. If I were to continue to make them that often I might substitute low/no fat sour cream or use yogurt cheese (drained yogurt) because sour cream is not a staple in our house. I didn't find them runny at all, but of course the potato size is key. Eyeball it. Mash with a masher, not a hand mixer which can give you glue. By the way, I made extra the second time and froze them individually for an easy treat later. Next time I will rub the skins with oil and salt to crisp them as other reviewers have suggested. YUM!

text:
The first time I made this, I did exactly as the recipe said minus the green onions. Ever since, I've always made them to accompany steak or ribs (really any meat product.) With a vegetarian in the house, I didn't add bacon into the mixture, but still as a topping it tasted great. (Although in the mixture is just as delicious tasting c:) I always add cheese into the mixture AND on top. If you use half-slices of your favorite kind of cheese (tastes great with Colby Jack and Cheddar) on top and put bacon underneath, it's just delicious. I also add Nature's Seasoning Salt along with the pepper and salt and it does make a difference! This is a wonderful, easy recipe that's great for families, big or small. Love love love this recipe!

text:
I made this for a cookout and it was a huge hit! Everyone loved them. My husband told me this is what we should bring to every group event we go to. I used the recipe more as a guideline since I made so many. ( I used two bags of Idaho potatoes, so maybe 20 whole potatoes) I did use evaporated milk instead of regular and added garlic and onion powder to the potato mixture. I just added the sour cream and milk until the texture was smooth and then had my husband taste test to see if it tasted good before I filled the potatoes. Overall, this is a great recipe and a great comfort food.

text:
I used 10 potatoes, definetly a little longer than an hour in the oven, probably 75 minutes - keep checking after an hour.  A few edits:  I used good quality bacon bits from a jar (easier), light sour cream (healthier), garlic salt (instead of regular), and added tabasco to taste. I stuffed whole potatoes (cut a boat pattern in the tops to add mixture).  All else the same.  Magnifico!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I doubled the recipe and these came out great!  They were all gone by the time I had finished cooking the rest of the finger foods I was serving for a party (about 30 minutes alone with 12 people)  So I am basing my review on my husbands word of how they tasted and my experience cooking them.  I wrapped each potato up in aluminum foil & baked for 1.5 hr. on 350.  I scooped out the insides with no problems leaving some of it intact with the potato shell so they wouldn't break or fall to pieces.  I only used 1/2 the bacon that it called for.  Everyone at the party made a huge fuss over them!  I will be making this again maybe next time I may even get a bite!

text:
I didn't have large baking potatoes on hand, just normal russet potatoes. So I used 8 of them. That was probably too many as it made a huge amount and I had to use two baking sheets. This probably also messed with the proportions of the other ingredients as well. I would say that it's probably ultimately the bacon that makes this dish and since I don't eat bacon, using bacon bits was really just pointless (they're really not the same at all) and overall I found the potatoes a little bland without eat. I'm sure this is great with bacon, but without it, this definitely needs a bit more flavour pumped into it.

text:
This is an excellent, decadent recipe. Please, just try the recipe as it's written, it's perfect as is!  When I am making this and I want it to be on the lighter side, I simply double the amount of potatoes and use light sour cream and half the butter. Believe me, you won't tell the difference and no one else does either. Don't skimp on the bacon, get the best stuff you can, I get Applewood Smoked from Target. Makes a huge difference.

Everything is great about the recipe, except that 1 hour is not nearly enough to get the potatoes ready. I baked them for 90 minutes at 350 and they were still not soft! Ideally, potatoes need to be baked at a higher temperature. I recommend 425 degrees for 45 minutes to an hour.  But otherwise, delicious!

text:
These are very good, similar to how I usually make mine. I oil my potatoes before baking to get a very crisp skin and after they have cooled I use my melon baller to get in and scoop it out, best tool for the job hands down. You can also make this a great appy if you use nugget potatoes and a strawberry huller.. I recommend a pastry bag for the filling though as it is a bit meticulous for large quantities!

text:
My husband and daughter loved these. I rubbed the outside of the potatoes with olive oil and garlic salt prior to baking. I used smart balance butter, skim milk, and fat-free sour cream in addition to the rest of the ingredients. My family couldn't even taste the difference. Next time I will use reduced fat cheese since I am sure it would not taste any difference. I sprinkled cheese and bacon bits and then baked for about 15 minutes.

Display Name:
jenn

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good, basic recipe for twice-baked potatoes.  Spice it up your own way, it's hard to fail at this one!!  Just add what tastes good.  Unlike with mashed potatoes, you can't really "over-beat" these...I used my electric mixer and created a nice, whipped texture for the filling. Also, in my kitchen, time is usually of the essence, so I "baked" my potatoes in the microwave.  It's more steaming, really, and it saved me 40 mins at least!  I did finish them in the oven at 350 for about 15 mins, though.
To microwave your potatoes: Pierce your washed, wet (I don't dry them off) potatoes with a fork several times all around the potato.  Place wet potato on a MS plate, sprinkling a bit of water on your plate. If doing multiple potatoes, leave an inch of space between them, and only do two-3 medium sized baking potatoes at a time for even cooking.  Cook on high heat, about 7 mins for one potatoes, about 12 for two, and so on.  Carefully - don't burn yourself!- squish your potato to gauge it's texture inside.  Skin and flesh underneath should give nicely. Voila!  Baked potatoes in the microwave.

great recipe! like another reviewer said, I used smaller potatoes cut in half rubbed in olive oil and put face down on a tray cooked @ 450 for about 30 mins.. the part of potato that was face down gets a little hard but it still tastes good when you mash it out.. after the potatoes cooled I took a knife and outlined a circle to scoop out... followed the mixture exactly adding chives, bacon ranch dressing, and only a splash of milk. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow! What a good twice baked potato!!! Made these for dinner tonight, as an accompainment to flavorful flank steak (by Janice Montiverdi - on this site). I was skeptical at first.... I microwaved my potato (I only purchased one, enough for two servings) for the suggested amount of time per my "users manual" (yes, I save these!) and they were still rock solid! After cutting them in half and zapping for another couple of minutes, they were fork tender (whew!), but I could see them drying out if not watched carefully. My second "hurdle" was not using a big enough bowl to mix all the filling ingredients. My hand mixer would barely fit, so my potato mixture came out a bit lumpy (oh well - my bf prefers his this way...). I added bacon bits to the filling and sprinkled some on top as I did not have fresh bacon available. Baked as directed to "ultimate" perfection. This recipe now has a permanent place in my "keeper" file. Next time, I'll BAKE my potatoes and use a large mixing bowl to avoid the frustration.... I'd also like to try one reviewers idea for making "mini" stuffed reds as an appetizer. Oh, ya, and leave a thin shell (i.e. don't scoop all of the potato) or else you'll have problems filling them. Thank you SO much for sharing, Debra!

text:
Phenomenal!! I brushed the potatoes with oil and rubbed with garlic salt before baking. 
I only made 4 servings of these, and you MUST BE CAREFUL when adding the sour cream and milk. It will turn out runny if you put the whole amount in at once- I suggest adding a little, mixing, adding, mixing, until it is the consistency that you'd like. Otherwise, this is the perfect potato side dish-or even a meal in itself!! LOVE LOVE LOVE! :)

My grandma had a recipe for this and i couldn't quite remember the whole recipe this is the closest one to it the only thing that we did different that saves a hole bunch of time. We put each potato in the microwave for about 5 min then if they need to be put them in for 5 more but make sure you poke a few holes with a fork so you don't have a mess. And then we also add garlic powder to the potato mix they are delicious!!!!

text:
First time making twice baked potatoes, it was a success! This recipe is super easy, it was actually an after thought for new years and it was surprising that I had all the ingredients. My potatoes were a little small i cut the amount of sour cream to 3/4c, I think if they had been large the amount would be appropriate. the filling was a little lumpy, but I think maybe it was because I had my friend mix it and she's not that cooking saavy, but in any case if I notice it nexy time it would be hard to take a masher to that and make them smooth. Overall it was surprisingly easy and now I will just play with ingredients to give it that extra kick!

These are awesome.  My super picky kids even love this recipe.  Sometimes I cook the potatoes in the microwave and then mix all of the ingredients (skin and all) instead of placing the mixture back into the potato skins.  I just put some left over green onions, bacon pieces,and cheese on the top as a garnishment.  It makes the process a little faster AND I can take one big dish to church or whatever get together I'm going to.  People always request I make this dish.  Of course, I double the cheese and bacon!!!!

text:
These are just what i was craving.  i didn't add the bacon (i don't like bacon), and i added oregano to the mixture.  the oregano complimented the cheese, butter, and sour cream well.  i also added some grated parm cheese on top to help brown.  I prefer these to the ones at Fresh Market, they just need a little preparation time.  i did have to bake them 30-45 minutes longer initally so they would be soft enough to scoop the flesh out.

text:
I found the recipe very easy to use. Considering the size of the 2 potatoes I used, I ended up cooking them for about 1 hr 20 min.  Smaller potatoes would have been less time.  I did use 1/2 the sour cream that it called for and added cream cheese in its place.  I added 2 extra slices of bacon to the original recipe, added half the bacon to the mixture & the other half i sprinkled on top.  Regretfully, by putting the bacon in the mixture made the bacon soft.  Next time I will only put the bacon on top.  My husband really liked the potato & said it will be difficult to go back to a plain baked potato. Great recipe and a definate keeper
Review:

4

I guess we are some of the very few people who didn't care for this recipe.  I found the flavors to be really overwhelming, even though I cut back some on the bacon and green onions. I think I will continue to just make my basic twice baked potatoes recipe that I've had for years.  Sorry.

text:
Now I know where this recipe got it's name. These were fabulous! This was my first time make twice baked potatoes but not my last! There were a couple of things I did different. I cooked them at 425 degrees for 50 minutes. I added a 1/2 tsp of onion salt and a clove of fresh garlic. Like another reviewer, I rubbed them in olive oil and sprinkled them with course Kosher salt. Great flavor. They were a huge hit at my dinner party, even with my 7 year who had seconds! I would definitely recommed these to everyone. They are fabulous. Thanks Debra.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/422872.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really liked the idea of this recipe, but the first time I made them, I had a little trouble.  I bought 4 large baking potatoes and baked them for an hour, but they were no where near done. I nuked them for awhile, but then second guessed myself and thought maybe the skins would "stand up" better if they were not quite all the way done.  Nope.  I cut them and dug them out the best that I could and mashed the filling with butter and sour cream etc. they were only a little lumpy.  I did try to serve them in the skins...I mangled a couple of them, but luckily we only had one other couple over so it worked out ok.  They tasted wonderful.  I made them again and instead of baking the potatoes, I basically made regular mashed potatoes (boiling) and added the ingredients from this recipe.  Same great flavor, but without the fuss.  That bacon makes them soooooo good!

These turned out great!  Instead of baking them I wrapped them in foil and put them on the grill for about 30 minutes until fork tender.  Next, I scooped out the insides, added the ingredients as instructed and put the filled potatoes back on the grill for an additional 10 minutes or so.  The grill added a nice smokey flavor, too.

text:
As far as taste goes, this recipe is delicious!  I did encounter a few problems with it though.  Apparently an hour wasn't really long enough to soften the potatoes, so when I tried scooping out the insides, the skins got a little butchered.  So I did away with the skins and served it as is.  I also used a blender since the potatoes weren't soft enough to use a hand mixer.  I also used reduced fat sour cream, fat free cheddar cheese, and soy milk.  But like I said - the taste couldn't be beaten!

These are really good.  I cheated and I microwaved the potatoes for about 10 minutes and then wrapped them in tin foil for another 10 minutes. I think I might use a little less onion next time.

text:
I omitted the bacon and the onions, and cut back on the amounts of milk and sour cream, so the potatoes wouldn't be runny, and mixed them up with a hand mixer.  Then I just put cheese on top and these were wonderful!!  I baked them in a 425 oven for thirty minutes and they turned out great!  I made them for my in laws for dinner and got nothing but praise.  My husband loved them so much, he now wants me to make them at least twice a week!!  Great recipe!!
